The car features a simulated transmission fluid leak, mismatched hubcaps (and one exposed wheel painted [[school bus yellow]]), coat hanger antenna... and a supple leather-and-wood interior.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.break.com/usercontent/2007/10/chamelion-xle-383947 |title=Chamelion Xle |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Varenicline|Chantix]] — Two parodies for the prescription medication used to treat [[nicotine]] addiction and its advertising that uses "real people [with] real stories": ** The first, from 2012, lists mental side effects that are worse than nicotine addiction itself, which user [[Kristen Wiig]] slowly discovers she has, much to husband [[Bill Hader]]'s consternation (e.g. "If you notice changes in behavior such as a powerful, overwhelming desire to kill the person you love most, call your doctor right away.").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/chantix/n13339?snl=1 |title=''SNL'': Chantix |accessdate=14 Jan 2018}}</ref> ** The second ad, from 2018, emphasizes that Chantix user Kelly ([[Cecily Strong]]) is not an actress... although she's quick to correct that she once was, and spends the rest of the ad less praising Chantix and more resurrecting her long-dormant acting skills.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y_n8s44vxJE ''SNL'': Chantix Commercial] on YouTube (accessed 1/14/2018)</ref> * cheapkids.net – a website dedicated to the sale of shoddy items for babies and toddlers for irresponsible parents.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_4AbzZwMClc |title=Cheap kids.net |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Chess for Girls! – a parody of the marketing of children's toys based on gender, this [[chess]] set (unrelated to the chess game in general) features pieces with [[Barbie]] doll-style bodies and chess piece heads, an accompanying dollhouse, beachwear, minivan, bubble blower, and so on. The tag line: "A classic game of strategy and wits... and bubbles!"<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/282881/saturday-night-live-chess-for-girls |title=Saturday Night Live Chess for Girls |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Chewable Pampers – A line of Pampers diapers which contain flavor crystals that, once the diaper is soiled, turns into an edible treat.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/55587/saturday-night-live-pampers |title=Saturday Night Live Pampers |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Chia Head – a parody of both the [[Chia Pet]] and [[Minoxidil]]; men with bald or receding hairlines use this product to give them nice green hair just like a Chia Pet. ("Not to be used in salads!")<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/279566/saturday-night-live-chia-hair |title=Saturday Night Live Chia Hair |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * ''Chicago Improv'' — A promo for the latest series in producer [[Dick Wolf]]'s [[Chicago]]-based [[Chicago (franchise)|TV franchise]], with the city's [[improvisational theatre|improv comedy]] scene and those in it depicted in the same gritty, unflinching way as its [[Chicago Fire (TV series)|firefighting]] and [[Chicago P.D. (TV series)|law enforcement]] worlds.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7s5WrI3bZ8o ''SNL'': ''Chicago Improv'' promo] on YouTube (accessed 5/20/2018)</ref> * Chonk - This clothing store offers fashions that let women be "gorgeous at any size"; much to the models' clear dismay, however, the store bears an unflattering name. Also featured is "Lil' Chonk" for tween girls (the young model's concerned mother ushers her out of camera range), and the menswear store "Normal Clothes", where men can make a quick trip to find clothes in their size.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hRGKSwsD7ac "Chonk" on YouTube] (accessed 10/16/2016)</ref> * ''Chris Rock's White Person's Guide to Surviving The Apollo'' – [[Chris Rock]], a veteran of [[Harlem]]'s famed [[Apollo Theater]], promotes his video that gives tips to aspiring white comedians and singers on how to win over the Apollo's vociferously critical audiences. [[Siobhan Fallon Hogan|Siobhan Fallon]] and episode host [[Rob Morrow]] appear in before-and-after footage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://screen.yahoo.com/chris-rocks-white-persons-guide-000000315.html |title=Chris Rock's White Person's Guide to Surviving the Apollo |accessdate=1 Aug 2014}}</ref> * [[Tadalafil|Cialis]] Turnt - [[Taran Killam]] demonstrates the effects of "the only pill that combats your [[erectile dysfunction]] while giving you that unbeatable hip-hop sensation of "getting turnt". Users are shown dancing wildly to music exclaiming "Everybody get turnt!" that resembles [[Lil Jon]]'s song [[Turn Down for What]] (in the Hulu streaming version only. The original TV version actually had Lil Jon's "Turn Down for What").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/692461|title=Watch Saturday Night Live Online at Hulu|website=www.hulu.com}}</ref> * Citizens for a Better America – Dr. Swen Gazzara ([[Gilbert Gottfried]]) proves the value of hard work in America by asking [[Ronald Reagan]] to personally give him a "[[Fellatio|hum job]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/275139/saturday-night-live-citizens-for-a-better-america |title=Saturday Night Live Citizens For a Better America |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Clear-Rite – Karen ([[Kristen Wiig]]) speaks the praises of an "invisible" teeth retainer. The twist is that the product isn't real (it's superglue), Karen isn't her real name (it's Beth), and the ad isn't an ad (Beth's just practicing her pitch work before the bathroom mirror).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/08/08iclearrite.phtml |title=Clear-Rite transcript |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> * [[Clearasil]] – Appearing in ''SNL's'' recurring [[Sprockets (Saturday Night Live)|''Sprockets'']] skit, which parodied German pop culture, a young woman uses Clearasil (or, in a strong German accent, "Clärasil") to get rid of her pimples and impress her new boyfriend. The English word "[[pimples]]", however, is confused in the sketch with "pimplen", a strong German slang word with the same meaning as the English "[[fuck]]" (in the sexual sense). As a result, the commercial tagline ("mach das pimplen kaput") implies that Clearasil will destroy one's sex life.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.toadstoolblog.com/2007/09/toads-summer-faves.html |title=Toads' Summer Faves |accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> * Closet Organizer – A man in a blue Spandex suit ([[Will Forte]]) is hired to organize anything in a closet that someone throws in.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/124871/saturday-night-live-closet-organizer |title=Saturday Night Live Closet Organizer |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Clovin Hind Jeans – a parody of Calvin Klein Jeans commercials by Richard Avedon which featured numerous supermodels of the day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/264413/saturday-night-live-clovin-hind-jeans |title=Saturday Night Live Clovin Hind Jeans |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Cluckin' Chicken – a fast-food restaurant's animated mascot (voiced by [[Adam Sandler]]), when asked why he tastes so good, gleefully describes the process by which he is killed, decapitated and eviscerated, then flame-broiled (then, displaying a schematic chart, describes how he is consumed, digested, and eventually eliminated through defecation).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2317/saturday-night-live-cluckin-chicken |title=Saturday Night Live Cluckin Chicken |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * CNN Pregnancy Test – just like [[CNN|its namesake network]], this home pregnancy test delivers "relentless breaking news" alerts to a couple waiting (impatiently) to see if they're expecting a baby.<ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/snl-recap-seth-rogen-mocks-695686 Recap of 4/12/2014 ''Saturday Night Live''] from ''The Hollywood Reporter'', 4/13/2014</ref> * Coldcock [[Malt liquor|Malt Liquor]] – [[Tim Meadows]] appears in this parody of [[Billy Dee Williams]]' pitchwork for [[Colt 45 (malt liquor)|Colt 45]]; with each sip from a tall can of this beverage, an animated fist arises from the can's label to whack the drinker upside the jaw. [[Ellen Cleghorne]] ("I ain't afraid of no can of beer!") and [[Chris Rock]] also appear.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/coldcock/n10120 |title=''Saturday Night Live'': Coldcock |accessdate=3 Sep 2018}}</ref> * Colon Blow – In a parody of high-fiber cereal ads (notably [[Total (breakfast cereal)|Total]] and its "how many bowls" campaign), an off-screen voice tells cereal eater [[Phil Hartman]] he will need 30,000 bowls of his usual cereal to equal the fiber content in a single bowl of Colon Blow (2.5 million to equal Super Colon Blow, which is also promoted here). When the large numbers are quoted, a pyramid of the same number of bowls elevates Hartman into the ionosphere.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/colon-blow/n9822 |title=''Saturday Night Live'': Colon Blow |accessdate=3 Sep 2018}}</ref> * Colonel Belmont's Old Fashioned Horse Glue – [[Will Ferrell]] stars as Langford T. Belmont, a man whose family has been in the horse glue business for generations. It is a parody of commercials that try to appeal to old-fashioned values and tradition.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vigT0ucPWkA |title=Will Ferrell Colonel Belmont's Old Fashioned Horse Glue. Made the old fashioned way. Out of horses |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Complicit - a perfume specifically tailored for First Daughter [[Ivanka Trump]] (episode host [[Scarlett Johansson]]), who the voiceover positions as a glamorous yet duplicitous part of her controversial [[Donald Trump|father's]] ([[Alec Baldwin]]) [[Administration of Donald Trump|presidency]]. The tagline: "The fragrance for the woman who could stop all of this, but won't."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F7o4oMKbStE Complicit] on YouTube (accessed 3/13/2017)</ref> * Compulsion – a "Calvin Kleen" disinfectant, a parody of Calvin Klein's Obsession perfume and featuring an [[obsessive compulsive]] spokesmodel (played by [[Jan Hooks]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/264431/saturday-night-live-compulsion |title=Saturday Night Live Compulsion |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Cookie Dough Sport – parody of [[Gatorade]] sports drink for athletes who are having a hard time and eat cookie dough out of stress and depression.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.popscreen.com/v/63edW/Cookie-Dough-Sport |title=Cookie Dough Sport |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Corn Chip Nail Tips – [[Maya Rudolph]] and [[Tracy Morgan]] appear in this parody of "hip" [[potato chip]] commercials, promoting corn chips that double as false [[fingernails]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/275691/saturday-night-live-corn-chip-nail-tips |title=Saturday Night Live Corn Chip Nail Tips |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Count Chocula]] Silver – Count Chocula ([[Jimmy Fallon]]) promotes a newer version of his cereal that includes ingredients that help promote regularity and good heart health along with "kooky marshmallow bats! Bwa-ah-ah-ah-ah!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/02/02rcount.phtml |title=Count Chocula Silver |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * Cracklin' Oat Flakes (Now with [[ecstasy (drug)|Ecstasy]]) – [[Will Ferrell]] wakes up to find that he has run out of his normal cereal, Cracklin' Oat Flakes. His wife then offers Cracklin' Oat Flakes, Now with Ecstasy. After one bowl, Ferrell creeps out his coworkers, makes out with [[Chris Parnell]], then runs half-naked through the streets until he's seen in bed with a pacifier in his mouth and playing with a [[glowstick]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2343/saturday-night-live-cracklin-oat-flakes#s-p61-sr-i4 |title=Saturday Night Live: Cracklin Oat Flakes |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref> * Creeley's Soup – Off-screen announcer [[Bill Murray]] tries to talk a child ([[Gilda Radner]]) into exchanging the soup she's eating for various items. When she becomes annoyed ("No! Leave me alone! I'm eating!"), the announcer successfully talks her into not only stuffing corn from the soup into her nose but pouring the rest onto her nose ("Because the Soupman says so"). The product's tagline: "Creeley's Soup – The Child Handler".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/76/76rcreeleys.phtml |title=Creeley's Soup |accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> * ''The Crests and Troughs of Vernon Hawley, Jr.'' – This "special TV offer" promotes a 3-record compilation from "one of [[Country music|country's]] most enduring, yet erratic, superstars" (episode host [[John Larroquette]]), whose song repertoire deals with his [[alcoholism|battles with the bottle]] ("I hope you remember these ol' tunes.. 'cause I don't").<ref>[https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/vernon-hawley-jr/n9711 ''SNL'': "Vernon Hawley, Jr."] on NBC.com (accessed 10/7/2018)</ref> * [[Cricket Wireless]] — On the week when [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]] and the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] tested their [[Wireless Emergency Alerts|wireless alert]] system (one the [[White House]] would use only in a national emergency),<ref>[https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/10/3/17931894/emergency-alert-test-presidential-text "The new emergency alert system that lets Trump text you, explained,"] from Vox.com, 10/3/2018)</ref> this ad makes it appear that [[Donald Trump]] will use these "[[President of the United States|Presidential]] Alerts" to express the same type of opinions he shares on [[Donald Trump on social media#Twitter|Twitter]]. Luckily for those who use Cricket, they won't receive such endless alerts at all ("Now are you happy we have awful service?").<ref>[https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/emergency-alert/3808120 ''SNL'': "Emergency Alert"] on NBC.com (accessed 10/7/2018)</ref> * Cruz for Texas — Footage from a campaign rally makes up this ad for [[List of United States Senators from Texas|Texas Senator]] [[Ted Cruz]]'s ([[Beck Bennett]]) 2018 re-election effort. Cruz is assisted by a "hype team" ([[Kenan Thompson]] and episode host [[Awkwafina]]), but while the pair is able to liven up the crowd, things fall apart (literally and figuratively) for Cruz after he takes the stage.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QunBzjMchmA ''SNL'': "Ted Cruz Rally"] on YouTube (accessed 10/7/2018)</ref> * Crystal Gravy – A parody of the clear consumer products fad of the mid-1990s, specifically [[Crystal Pepsi]]. [[Julia Sweeney]] enjoys a drumstick dipped in clear gravy straight from the jar, while [[Kevin Nealon]] gleefully splashes his face in the clear, gooey liquid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/291086/saturday-night-live-crystal-gravy |title=Saturday Night Live Crystal Gravy |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref>
== D == * ''Dallas'': The Home Game – [[Charles Rocket]] pitches a home board game for [[dysfunctional family|dysfunctional families]] who can now act out their issues the same way the Ewings do on the prime time soap opera [[Dallas (1978 TV series)|''Dallas'']].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/282883/saturday-night-live-dallas |title=Saturday Night Live Dallas |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Damn It, My Mom is on Facebook – a computer application that bowdlerizes teenagers' photographed wild antics and rebellious opinions from their mothers who have added them as friends on [[Facebook]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/184577/saturday-night-live-moms-on-facebook |title=Saturday Night Live Mom's on Facebook |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Darnette Disposable Toilet – the toilet that you throw away after only one use. It takes just as many steps to install and remove as a regular toilet and costs $169.95.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/277893/saturday-night-live-darnette-disposable-toilets |title=Saturday Night Live Darnette Disposable Toilets |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * ''Daveheart'' – A movie trailer for a ''[[Braveheart]]'' sequel focusing on William Wallace's cowardly brother, Dave Wallace ([[Gerard Butler]]).<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/102969/saturday-night-live-daveheart |title=Saturday Night Live Daveheart |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * ''The Day Beyoncé Turned Black'' - a movie trailer interpreting the reaction to the release of [[Beyoncé]]'s [[Formation (song)|"Formation"]], a song noted for its embracing of black heritage, as an apocalyptic-style film, one where White Americans are hysterical over the realization that Beyoncé is black.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ociMBfkDG1w ''SNL'': "The Day Beyoncé Turned Black"] on YouTube (accessed 10/14/2017)</ref> * Dell Stator's 99-cent Toad Ranch – "Home of the World Famous Dell Stator Toad Pit and the Dell Stator Patented Broiling Method, where we can guarantee you the best 99-cent toad steak you'll ever eat!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75udell.phtml |title=Dell Stator's Toad Ranch Restaurant |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] 2018 Campaign — [[Progressivism in the United States|Progressive-leaning]] voters express confidence in this ad that Democratic candidates will win in the [[United States elections, 2018|midterm elections]] and put the [[administration of Donald Trump]] in check... despite being visibly worried (e.g. sweaty armpits, nervous voices) over the possibility of a [[Blue Wave 2018|"blue wave"]] not materializing. The closing tag line: "Vote! Please?"<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdNNjCHGixE ''SNL'': "Midterm Ad"] on YouTube (accessed 11/4/2018)</ref> * [[Depend (undergarment)|Depend]] Legends — Incontinent yet ashamed to wear adult diapers? You don't have to be when Depend offers a line of diapers with images of classic stars of the past (e.g. [[Clark Gable]], [[Jack Paar]], [[Mickey Mantle]]). The tagline: "Make History. In your pants."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hH33lLVsYBU ''SNL'': Depend Legends] on YouTube (accessed 2/14/2018)</ref> * [[Derek Jeter]]'s Taco Hole – Derek Jeter pitches a [[taco]] restaurant in [[Nutley, New Jersey]], with a jingle sung to the [[Beach Boys]] song "[[Kokomo (song)|Kokomo]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/124969/saturday-night-live-derek-jeters-taco-hole |title=Saturday Night Live Derek Jeter's Taco Hole |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Dillon/Edwards Investments – this 1999 ad promotes a financial firm that took a slow, cautious approach to providing services on the internet; when they were ready to do so, they took the only [[domain name]] available: "www.clownpenis.fart".<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/dillon-edwards-investments/n11241?snl=1 ''SNL'': "Dillon/Edwards Investments] on NBC.com (accessed 12/18/2017)</ref> * Disco Meltdown – A Season 6 ad promotes a hip, new dance club in the [[nuclear reactor core|reactor core]] of a [[nuclear power plant]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/264416/saturday-night-live-disco-meltdown |title=Saturday Night Live Disco Meltdown |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Disney Channel]] Acting School — [[Miley Cyrus]] (as herself) and [[Raven-Symoné]] ([[Kenan Thompson]]) promote a school where students train to act "the Disney way," learning techniques such as "Disrespecting Authority," "Pause Then Dis," and "Reacting To Stinky Feet."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MeSd7Q7oThc ''SNL'': Disney Channel Acting School] on YouTube (accessed 2/17/2018)</ref> * Dissing Your Dog – [[Will Ferrell]] sells a dog training video for [[passive aggressive]] dog owners.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/284575/saturday-night-live-dissing-your-dog |title=Saturday Night Live Dissing Your Dog |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * ''Divided We Stand'' — This ad promotes an [[Off-Broadway]] musical that dives head first into the contentious American political climate, though its book, songs, and cast leave a bad impression on not only critics ("''[[Time Out (magazine)#Time Out New York|Time Out New York]]'' calls it 'Dangerously oversimplified'") but audiences ("I guess the worst part of the play was their confidence in it").<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YBy6Fnyss4c ''SNL'': "Political Musical"] on YouTube (accessed 11/6/2018)</ref> * [[Donald Trump]]'s House of Wings – his own chicken wing restaurant, featuring Donald Trump as himself, [[Horatio Sanz]] as [[David Crosby]], and four other castmembers ([[Seth Meyers]], [[Kenan Thompson]], [[Amy Poehler]] and [[Maya Rudolph]]) as singing employees in chicken costumes. The jingle is set to "[[Jump (For My Love)]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/03/03pwings.phtml |title=Donald Trump's House of Wings |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Don't Buy Stuff You Can't Afford – Pitchman [[Chris Parnell]] promotes a book about money management to a clueless couple ([[Amy Poehler]] and episode host [[Steve Martin]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/1389/saturday-night-live-dont-buy-stuff |title=Saturday Night Live Don't Buy Stuff |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Dopenhagen and Happy Daze – [[David Carradine]] plays a cowboy who likes to get high on [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] he can chew instead of smoke. Parody of [[Copenhagen tobacco|Copenhagen]] chewing tobacco.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/264412/saturday-night-live-dopenhagen-and-happy-daze |title=Saturday Night Live Dopenhagen and Happy Daze |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Dr. Porkenheimer's Boner Juice – parody of [[erectile dysfunction]] treatments (particularly [[Levitra]]), complete with the warning "If you experience an erection lasting longer than twenty-four hours, call up your friends and brag about it." Levitra's slogan "strong and lasting" is replaced by "thick and sturdy".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x4rkbm_dr-porkenheimer-s-boner-juice_fun |title=Dr. Porkenheimer's Boner Juice |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Dr. Uncle Jimmy's Smokehouse and Outpatient Surgical Facility – A shady clinic that offers semi-professional surgery and mediocre barbecue cuisine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/07/07gsmokehouse.phtml |title=Dr. Uncle Jimmy's Smokehouse and Outpatient Surgical Facility |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Dropping the L.B.'s With Missy E – [[Missy Elliott]] ([[Tracy Morgan]]) pitches a workout video featuring her impossible-to-imitate dance moves.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/02/02emissye.phtml |title=Dropping The L.B.'s With Missy E |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Duncan Hines]] Brownie Husband – a brownie treat shaped like a life-sized man, designed specifically for the single woman.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/141546/saturday-night-live-brownie-husband |title=Saturday Night Live Brownie Husband |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Dunkin Donuts]] — An ad featuring "Actual Customers," all of whom are professional and telegenic for the camera... except for Donny (episode host [[Casey Affleck]]), who sports a thick [[Boston accent]] and a rude, uncouth disposition toward Dunkin's staff and customers.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FSvNhxKJJyU ''SNL'': Dunkin Donuts] on YouTube (accessed 2/15/2018)</ref> * DynaCorp – an announcer (voice of [[Chris Parnell]]) confuses [[Jessica Simpson]] with food products similar to [[Chicken of the Sea]]-brand tuna. The ad parodies Simpson's remark on the [[MTV]] reality show ''[[Newlyweds: Nick and Jessica]]'', where she asked [[Nick Lachey]] if Chicken of the Sea was tuna or chicken.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/03/03jdynacorp.phtml |title=DynaCorp |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Dyson Toilet – Parody of [[Dyson (company)|Dyson]] vacuum cleaner ads.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2339/saturday-night-live-dyson |title=Saturday Night Live Dyson |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== E == * [[Ed McMahon]]'s School of Laughing — a school that trains people who want to make money by performing on [[laugh track]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/275130/saturday-night-live-ed-mcmahon-school-of-laughing |title=Saturday Night Live Ed McMahon School of Laughing |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]] Express — an [[express courier]] service that handles late-arriving packages by literally sending them back in [[time]] to the desired arrival date. The slogan: "When it absolutely, positively has to be there the day before yesterday".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/264060/saturday-night-live-einstein-express |title=Saturday Night Live Einstein Express |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Elián! The Cuban Boy — promo for a [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]-produced Broadway musical about [[Elián González]] (the real-life young boy turned over to his father in Cuba after resistance from relatives in Florida), with [[Christopher Walken]] as [[Fidel Castro]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/278014/saturday-night-live-elian-the-cuban-boy |title=Saturday Night Live Elian the Cuban Boy |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Empire (2015 TV series)|Empire]]'' – a promo parody of the [[FOX]] television series, now including a white man named Chip (played by [[Chris Hemsworth]]) who would rather run the record company as a real company instead of getting involved in the drama. * "Energy for a Gullible America" — parodies [[Exxon]]'s "Energy for a Strong America" campaign. [[Don Pardo]] is the voiceover announcer for a spot decrying high production costs for elaborate oil-company commercials and offering this as an excuse for high energy prices.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/76/76toxxon.phtml |title=Oxxon |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * The Englehart Five — The [[Germany|German]] [[quintet]]'s new album has Helga Englehart (episode host [[Eva Longoria]]) and her brothers Rolf, Fritz, and Juergen (played respectively by [[Fred Armisen]], [[Bill Hader]], and [[Seth Meyers]]) singing songs about their brother Klaus' ([[Will Forte]]) death in a hunting accident caused by Rolf.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/05/05fenglehart.phtml |title=Englehart Five |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Epoxy-Dent — A 1978 ad for "the strongest denture cream permitted by law". To prove its strength, a user bites down on a wood bar, which is lifted by a helicopter ("The Epoxy-Dent Chopper Test!").<ref>[http://snltranscripts.jt.org/78/78gepoxydent.phtml Transcript for "Epoxy-Dent"] from SNLTranscripts.JT.org</ref> * EPT Home Pregnancy Test - a parody of EPT's campaign that features real-life couples using the product to see if they're having a baby. Here, a man and woman ([[Seth Meyers]] and [[Amy Poehler]]) await the results of the test — and nervously so, as they're really two college students who had a one-night stand two weeks earlier.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kFb5fkuL4ew ''SNL'': EPT Home Pregnancy Test] on YouTube (accessed 9/20/2017)</ref> * Estro-maxx – Going through a male-to-female sex change is easier with Estro-maxx, a once-a-day pill that gives you all the hormones you need. Caused minor controversy for its depictions of male-to-female transsexuals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/211062#s-p36-sr-i4 |title=Saturday Night Live Estro-maxx |accessdate=5 August 2012}}</ref> * EternaRest Coffin Mattresses — casket padding that outlasts the corpse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/94/94eeternarest.phtml |title=Eterna-Rest |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Eych! — "Eych! It's the only hairball remover that [[cats]] ask for by name." A spoof of [[Meow Mix]], but instead the cats cough in an exceedingly funny manner.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2355/saturday-night-live-eych |title=Saturday Night Live Eych |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Excedrin]] RT — [[Queen Latifah]] plays a businesswoman who takes an [[aspirin]] to combat "racial tension" headaches (the "RT" in the product name) brought on by interns asking questions about the stereotypical behavior of black people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/1605/saturday-night-live-excedrin-for-racial-tension-headaches#s-p64-sr-i4 |title=Saturday Night Live: Excedrin for Racial Tension Headaches |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref> * Exclusive Connections — [[Paris Hilton]] promotes a sex chat line catering to nerds who are interested in science fiction and fantasy movies.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/04/04kexclusive.phtml |title=Exclusive Connections |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * EZ Date — Parody of [[eHarmony]] and other [[matchmaking]] websites. All of the matches are alluded to be between [[prostitution|prostitute]] and [[wikt:Client|client]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2311/saturday-night-live-e-z-date |title=Saturday Night Live E-Z Date |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== F == * FX-70 Cheese Slicer – [[Candice Bergen]] pitches a [[Instant camera|Polaroid]] camera that dispenses cheese slices.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/76/76jcheese.phtml |title=FX-70 Cheese Slicer |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * ''The Fault in Our Stars 2: The Ebola in Our Everything'' — A trailer for a sequel to [[The Fault in Our Stars (film)|the 2014 film]] about two teens with cancer who fall in love, only here Olive (episode host [[Sarah Silverman]]) has the [[Ebola virus disease|Ebola virus]]), which severely tampers paramour Theodore's ([[Taran Killam]]) attraction to her.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DopEzgBk4dA ''SNL'': ''The Fault in Our Stars 2''] on YouTube (accessed 9/3/2018)</ref> * ''Fear Factor, Jr.'' – A [[Saturday Night Live (season 29)|season 29]] promo for the latest installment of the NBC reality show ''[[Fear Factor]]'' with [[Joe Rogan]] ([[Fred Armisen]]) coercing children to perform dangerous and disgusting stunts just as he does with adults on the regular ''Fear Factor''. For example, one kid will have to watch his parents (including [[Saturday Night Live (season 30)|Season 30]] cast member [[Rob Riggle]]) divorce if he can't eat a plate of maggot-ridden eggs Benedict.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freevlog.hu/video/9809.html |title=Fear Factor Junior |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Federline – [[Kevin Federline]] ([[Ashton Kutcher]]) pitches his new line of underwear to extricate himself from the shadow of his wife [[Britney Spears]]; shot in black-and-white, similar in style to early [[Calvin Klein]] commercials.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.56.com/u33/v_MTY0MjY0NTQ.html |title=Kevin Federline- SNL – Ashton Kutcher – Federline Briefs |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Felina Cat Food – In a parody of onsite supermarket taste-test commercials, a TV pitchman dupes a housewife into eating tuna casserole made from cat food.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75cfelina.phtml |title=Felina Cat Food |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * First CityWide Change Bank – Two ads promote a financial institution whose only service is providing change (e.g. "you come to us with 16 quarters, 8 dimes, and 4 nickels, we can give you a 5 dollar bill"). How does First CityWide make money doing this? As one service rep says it, "The answer is simple: Volume".<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/first-citywide-change-bank/n9701?snl=1 ''SNL'': First CityWide Change Bank ad #1] on NBC.com (accessed 3/25/2018)</ref><ref>[https://view.yahoo.com/show/saturday-night-live/clip/4616898/first-citywide-change-bank-2 ''SNL'': First CityWide Change Bank ad #2] via Yahoo.com (accessed 3/25/2018)</ref> * Flex – deodorant laced with [[steroid]]s that provoke its users to behave like animals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/278941/saturday-night-live-flex |title=Saturday Night Live Flex |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> * Fresh Squeezed Baseball — Episode host [[Bob Uecker]] starts his day off right with juice freshly pureed (seams and all) from baseballs.<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/fresh-squeezed/n9249?snl=1 ''SNL'': Fresh Squeezed Baseball] on NBC.com (accessed 3/25/2018)</ref> * Frozen Mexican Dinner – Musician [[Paul Brittain]] is not feeling well during his band's recording session, claiming constipation. Luckily, bandmate [[Fred Armisen]] offers this frozen food product with medicine designed to counter constipation ("you eat it, and ''ay ay ay!''"). Also available in [[Indian cuisine|Indian]] and fish varieties.<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/frozen-mexican-dinner/n13293?snl=1 ''SNL'': Frozen Mexican Dinner] on NBC.com (accessed 3/25/2018)</ref> * ''The Fruiting'' – a movie trailer spoof for a horror flick where citrus fruits attack a family living in a haunted mansion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/264430/saturday-night-live-the-fruiting |title=Saturday Night Live The Fruiting |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== G == * ''[[The Game of Life]]: [[Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals|DACA]] Edition'' — from April 2018, this topical variation on the classic [[board game]] forces players who pull a "[[DREAM Act|dreamer]]" card to take an alternative path where they must "work three jobs," dodge [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]] agents, and face bureaucratic hoops. The simulation of (and references to) real life clearly drains one player's ([[Melissa Villaseñor]]) joy in the game.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1TWo74L8EiY ''SNL'': ''The Game of Life: DACA Edition''] on YouTube (accessed 4/8/2018)</ref> * ''Gandhi and the Bandit'' – A movie trailer spoofing ''[[Smokey and the Bandit]]'', with law enforcement chasing a speeding 18-wheeler driven by [[Mahatma Gandhi]] ([[Tim Kazurinsky]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/83/83lgandhi.phtml |title=Gandhi and the Bandit |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Gangsta Bitch Barbie – new [[Barbie]] doll perpetuates stereotypes of black people living in the ghetto (the doll comes with [[Jolly Ranchers]], a pack of [[Newport (cigarette)|Newports]], and a [[restraining order]] against her boyfriend, [[Tupac Shakur|Tupac]] Ken). Parodies use of [[hip hop culture]] in advertisement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/291080/saturday-night-live-gangsta-bh-barbie |title=Saturday Night Live Gangsta B**h Barbie |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref> * Galactic Prophylactic – Excited pitchman [[Eddie Murphy]] promotes [[Ron Popeil]]-produced male [[prophylactic]]s constructed with a steel core for extra durability. Also promoted is the Dura-Fram Diaphragm for women.<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/popiel/2869153?snl=1 ''SNL'': Popeil Galactic Prophylactic] on NBC.com (accessed 3/17/2018)</ref> * Gary Busey Motorcycle Helmet – following [[Gary Busey]]'s near-fatal helmetless motorcycle crash, this clip features [[Phil Hartman]] as Busey endorsing a new line of protective headgear. On top of the helmet is an enormous foam rubber "helmet protector", and also mentioned a "helmet protector protector", which was too large to be shown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/276404/saturday-night-live-gary-busey-ad |title=Saturday Night Live Gary Busey Ad |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Gary Hart for President Committee — this sensually-shot ad finds a scorned woman ([[Jan Hooks]]) fighting in vain to put [[Gary Hart]] behind her, but Hart is there to remind her (and voters) that "you can't get him out of your mind," no matter what he may have done (an allusion to the allegations of extramarital affairs that plagued the charismatic Hart's campaign for U.S. President in the late 1980s).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/278936#s-p19-sr-i4 |title=Saturday Night Live Hart Ad |accessdate=5 August 2012}}</ref> * Gas Right – Inventor Bruce Johnson ([[Fred Armisen]]) modifies his Breathe-Right [[nasal strip]]s to a larger size that expands the buttocks and prevents nighttime flatulence noises.<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/gas-right/n12387?snl=1 ''SNL'': Gas Right] on NBC.com (accessed 3/17/2018)</ref> * Gaystrogen – a parody of the [[Estroven]] [[hormone]] drug; for men over 45 suffering from "queer loss".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://video.canadiancontent.net/51238629-gaystrogen.html |title=Gaystrogen |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Gidget]] Goes to [[Electroconvulsive therapy|Shock Therapy]] — This ad features three grown women acting like little girls, the result of "Gidget's Disease," a condition [[psychiatrist]] [[Jane Curtin]] says makes them "terminally cute... too cute for their own good." The only cure is a form of "pointless root canal" in "The Dental Theater of Cruelty."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/76/76ogidget.phtml |title=Gidget's Disease |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Girls Gone Wild (franchise)|Girls Gone Wild]]: Katrina'' — [[Doug Stanhope]] ([[Jason Sudeikis]]) travels to a flooded post-[[Hurricane Katrina]] [[New Orleans]] and offers women fresh water and clothing in exchange for their flashing their breasts and "going wild" for the camera.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/05/05agirls.phtml |title=Girls Gone Wild Katrina |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Googie Rene's — In two ads, Googie ([[Kenan Thompson]]) promotes his seasonal discount clothing shops where you can save big on clothes with obvious imperfections including: **Googie Rene's Partially Damaged Halloween Costume Discount Basement, whose costumes are so stained and torn you need props to hide the imperfections (and both costumes and props have suspicious odors).<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=48_njDKfVzg ''SNL'': Googie Rene's Partially Damaged Halloween Costume Discount Basement] on YouTube (accessed 7/19/2018)</ref> **Googie Rene's Slightly Damaged Prom Wear Barn, featuring dresses with grass stains on the backside and tuxedos with meatball stains on the front (the previous wearer fell asleep in a plate of spaghetti).<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_u7E4UYzN1Y ''SNL'': Googie Rene's Slightly Damaged Prom Wear Barn] on YouTube (accessed 6/3/2018)</ref> * ''The Goombahs'' — Cashing in on the success of [[HBO]]'s ''[[The Sopranos]]'', [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] creates its own show about a stereotypical [[Italian-American]] family. The promo's tagline: "Television at its finest. And its most Italian."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/99/99ogoombahs.phtml |title=The Goombahs |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * GoProbe — A trio of extreme athletes ([[Taran Killam]], [[Kyle Mooney]], and [[Beck Bennett]]) promote this special version of the [[GoPro]] camera designed for use by doctors in [[colonoscopy]] exams.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qTGauBXL_sE ''SNL'': GoProbe] on YouTube (accessed 7/8/2018)</ref> * GP Yass — Liven up your long trip by adding this mode to your [[GPS navigation device]] that uses a [[drag performer]]'s voice (and attitude) to deliver directions.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DmkPpA2RT-Y ''SNL'': "GP Yass"] on YouTube (accessed 11/19/2018)</ref> * ''Grable and Lombard'' — A movie trailer spoof about the [[lesbian]] wedding of [[Betty Grable]] and [[Carole Lombard]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75ograble.phtml |title=Grable and Lombard/Goodnights |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Grady Wilson DVDs — Grady Wilson ([[Kenan Thompson]]) promotes two DVDs that teach married couples his best sexual moves, all bizarre yet humorously demonstrated by Grady and his assistants in what appears to be his garage. The DVDs include: ** ''Grady Wilson's Burning Up the Sheets'', in which Grady and Amber (episode host [[Megan Fox]]) perform moves such as "The Striking 12" and "The Skydiver."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X7uUfrOj6MU ''SNL'': "Googie Wilson's Burning Up the Sheets"] on YouTube (accessed 7/27/2018)</ref> ** ''Grady Wilson's Fifty & Freaky'', with Grady and Marta from [[Amsterdam]] (episode host [[Sigourney Weaver]]) demonstrating "The Sun Is In My Eyes," "The Old TV" ("Any picture yet?"), and other techniques for couples over 50.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wSR3n5cCS1o ''SNL'': "Grady Wilson's Fifty & Freaky"] on YouTube (accessed 7/27/2018)</ref> * Graffiti: Say No – [[New York City]] mayor [[Rudolph Giuliani]] cracks down on graffiti artists defacing the city by adding insults next to their handiwork. * Grayson Moorhead Securities – A lampoon of [[broker|brokerage companies]] projecting a tradition of competence and trustworthiness, where the founding principles include making a list of clients, investing in white-owned businesses, and keeping the list in a safe place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/61335/saturday-night-live-moorhead-securities |title=Saturday Night Live Moorhead Securities |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Green & Fazio — Attorney Barry Green ([[Phil Hartman]]) and his firm specializes in personal injury cases including phantom whiplash, near-collision stress, trauma suffered by accident bystanders, and pain suffered while committing burglary, not to mention harassing defendants to settle.<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/green-fazio-i/2860967?snl=1 ''SNL'': Green & Fazio I] on NBC.com (accessed 3/17/2018)</ref><ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/green-fazio-ii/2860968?snl=1 ''SNL'': Green & Fazio II] on NBC.com (accessed 3/17/2018)</ref> * Grimaldi's Classic Creations — [[Nativity scene]] figurines including a Baby Jesus that, thanks to a sound microchip, screams 24 hours a day from Christmas Day to Three Kings Day (January 6), much to the consternation of mom [[Nancy Carell|Nancy Walls]], dad [[David Koechner]], and the family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/95/95ggrimaldi.phtml |title=SNL Transcripts: Anthony Edwards: 12/02/95: Grimaldi's Classic Creations |publisher=Snltranscripts.jt.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-19}}</ref> * Gun City – a [[Crazy Eddie]]-type pitchman ([[Joe Piscopo]]) offers firearms as Christmas presents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/275207/saturday-night-live-gun-city |title=Saturday Night Live Gun City |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Guns — The firearms industry would like to remind you that a gun is perfect for any major or minor life event, from professions of love to jogging in the park to welcoming your first child into the world. The tagline: "Guns. We're here to stay."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SwEyBItsXkw ''SNL'': Guns] on YouTube (accessed 7/18/2018)</ref> * ''[[Guy Fieri]]'s Full Throttle Christmas Special'' — [[Food Network]] host Fieri ([[Bobby Moynihan]]) presents a holiday special with his unique dishes and featuring appearances from "the human equivalent of the food he makes," like [[Kid Rock]] ([[Brooks Wheelan]]), [[Criss Angel]] ([[Kyle Mooney]]), [[Bret Michaels]] ([[Taran Killam]]), [[Kimbo Slice]] ([[Kenan Thompson]]), Mimi from ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'' ([[Aidy Bryant]]), [[Verne Troyer]] ([[John Milhiser]]), [[Angela Raiola | Big Ang]] ([[Kate McKinnon]]), [[Duane Chapman | Dog the Bounty Hunter]] ([[John Goodman]]) and the cast of ''[[Pawn Stars]]'' (all played by Moynihan). <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=moEH8P-Z4D8|title=Guy Fieri's Full Throttle Christmas Special - SNL|first=|last=Saturday Night Live|date=15 December 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
== H == * [[Hallmark Cards|Hallmark]] Mother Collection — [[Mother's Day]] cards that "crazy weirdo" sons who enjoy dressing up and acting like their mothers can give themselves ("because you're not just a good son, you're also a wonderful mother").<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hOkc45IJC0g ''SNL'': "Hallmark Mother Collection"] on YouTube (accessed 6/3/2018)</ref> * [[Hamburger Helper]] Antibacterial - [[Chris Parnell]] pitches this food product that includes the "powerful antibacterial agent" Tristanex to a grocery-shopping couple ([[Will Ferrell]] and [[Ana Gasteyer]]) unsure if the days-old hamburger meat in their [[refrigerator]] is safe to eat. Parnell's cooking demonstration reveals, despite the product's acrid smell, that the meat's "germ volume is almost cut in half" (by 37.99% to be precise). Also promoted is Chicken Helper with Chlorine Bleach.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/99/99ihamburger.phtml|title=SNL Transcripts: Jamie Foxx: 01/08/00: Hamburger Helper Antibacterial - SNL Transcripts Tonight|date=8 October 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * Handi-Off – a [[topical]] treatment used for removal of excess fingers. ("Also try new 'Toe-Riffic!'")<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KjJ5xolc6GE |title=Handi Off SNL |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Hands-Free Selfie Stick — A traditional [[selfie stick]] needs to be held with one hand. Not this version, whose long, bendable arm reaches out over the user and is inserted (inconveniently) up their buttocks. Episode host [[Amy Schumer]] ("It takes pictures?") makes an endorsement cameo.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IJ49fj6iXEo ''SNL'': "Hands-Free Selfie Stick"] on YouTube (accessed 5/11/2018)</ref> * [[Happy Fun Ball]] – a seemingly simple children's toy with dozens of [[disclaimer]]s for absurdly dangerous health hazards and life-threatening properties, notably among them "Do not taunt Happy Fun Ball" and "Happy Fun Ball may stick to certain types of skin."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7gzDC-2ZO8I |title=Happy Fun Ball (old SNL spoof commercial) |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Harley's Bristol Cream – a parody of [[Harvey's Bristol Cream]], in which [[Gilda Radner]] uses the phone to find dates and then calls out to people on the street via opening the window.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.videolog.tv/video.php?id=456266 |title=Harley's Bristol Cream – SNL |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * ''Have a Nice Day'' – a trailer for a horror movie where smiley faces haunt potential [[murder]] victims.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacafe.com/watch/hl-40032735/saturday_night_live_have_a_nice_day_season_6/ |title=Saturday Night Live – Have a Nice Day Season: 6 |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Headz Up – An [[iPhone]] text-based app that clues people to their surroundings and keeps them out of danger while their eyes are glued to their tech devices. * Hedley and Wyche — An ad for "the [[United Kingdom|British]] toothpaste," one infused with "two teaspoons of pure cane sugar... for a smile that says, 'Yum, that was good.'" A spoof of the [[stereotype]] that the Brits, by and large, maintain poor dental hygiene.<ref>[https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/hedly-and-wyche/n10017 ''SNL'': Hedley and Wyche] on NBC.com (accessed 6/14/2018)</ref> * Hey, You – [[Gilda Radner]] appears in this ad for a [[perfume]] for women in search of a [[one-night stand]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/77/77gheyyou.phtml |title=Hey, You! |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Helmsley Spook House – [[Leona Helmsley]] (played by [[Nora Dunn]]) creates a haunted house with the same style, class, and obedient workers as her hotels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/275692/saturday-night-live-helmlsey-spook-house |title=Saturday Night Live Helmlsey Spook House |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Herbal Essences]] for Men — Attorney [[Amy Poehler]] has already "got the urge," but opposing counsel [[Will Ferrell]] and other men in the courtroom get it too in this parody of [[Clairol]]'s playfully sensual ad campaign for its shampoo line.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OFg22oc9rmE ''SNL'': "Herbal Essence for Men"] on YouTube (accessed 7/27/2018)</ref> * Herman & Sons Sperm Bank — George Herman (episode host [[Seth Rogen]]) and Eugene Sons ([[Kenan Thompson]]) announce a going out of business sale at "the oldest sperm bank in greater [[Lansing, Michigan|Lansing]];" they're turning the space into a [[TCBY]] franchise, so they need to get rid of their sperm stock to assure "minimal sperm-to-yogurt crossover."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sk9rnNC--Nk&t=0s ''SNL'': Herman & Sons Sperm Bank] on YouTube (accessed 7/19/2018)</ref> * HiberNol – parody of [[NyQuil]] ads featuring a cold medicine designed to knock a person out for the entire cold and flu season. [[Phil Hartman]] appears as the onscreen announcer. "From the makers of Coma-Dose!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/3534/saturday-night-live-hibernol |title=Saturday Night Live HiberNol |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Hire The Incompetent – a [[Temporary work|temp agency]] that offers unskilled workers for hire; first appearance of [[Gilda Radner]]'s recurring character [[Roseanne Roseannadanna]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/77/77dincompetent.phtml |title=Hire the Incompetent |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * ''Holding Your Own Boobs'' Magazine – ad for a magazine featuring male and female celebrities [[handbra|cupping their breasts]]; spoofs the numerous copy-cat magazine covers that re-created Janet Jackson's famous 1993 ''Rolling Stone'' cover. Features [[Sarah Michelle Gellar]] and [[Will Ferrell]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ipernity.com/doc/103715/5096964 |title=SMG Holding your own boobs SNL |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Home Security Decoy – [[mannequin]]s posing as criminals already breaking into a house to trick real thieves into thinking it's already being robbed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/285844/saturday-night-live-home-security-decoys |title=Saturday Night Live Home Security Decoys |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Homocil – a special drug that helps reduce the stress of parents whose male children express [[homosexual]] tendencies. The tag line: "Because it's your problem, not theirs."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YmzfiTa1pmM |title=Homocil – SNL |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> * Hoverboards — This December 2015 ad plays up on the popularity of [[self-balancing scooter]]s and their propensity to catch fire (it's the gift that says "I hate walking, but I love fires").<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pgCi-a6PyBA ''SNL'': "Hoverboards"] on YouTube (accessed 9/11/2018)</ref> * ''How to Order Sushi Like a CEO'' – a pompous executive (episode host [[Matt Dillon]]) promotes his book (that he hired someone else to write) on how to order at sushi restaurants, all the while patronizing sushi restaurant waitress [[Maya Rudolph]] ("Anything else, Mr. Douche?").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/ordering-sushi-like-a-ceo/n12026 |title=''Saturday Night Live'': "Ordering Sushi Like a CEO" |accessdate=11 Sep 2018}}</ref> * HuckaPM — How does [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] ([[Aidy Bryant]]), sleep at night after a long day of making outlandish statements in defense of the [[administration of Donald Trump|Trump administration]]? With this [[sleep aid]] that combines [[Melatonin]], extra strength quaaludes, and the "One and Dones" prescribed to [[Michael Jackson]] by his doctor. One tablet and Sanders is instantly asleep.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZGmnXiZYGA ''SNL'': "HuckaPM"] on YouTube (accessed 11/4/2018)</ref> * Huggies Thong – useless diapers shaped like [[G-string|thongs]]; parodies the increasing phenomenon of the sexualization of young children, and parents who allow their children to dress in risqué, revealing clothing more suited for adults.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.myspace.com/video/nichole/snl-diaper-thong-skit/55142013 |title=SNL Diaper Thong Skit |accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref>
== I == * Infiniti Toilets — [[Mike Myers (actor)|Mike Myers]] in a toilet ad (same style as the [[Jonathan Pryce]] [[Infiniti J30]] commercials).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/291279/saturday-night-live-infiniti-toilet |title=Saturday Night Live Infiniti Toilet |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Interbank — A husband and wife ([[Will Ferrell]] and [[Molly Shannon]]) extol the aforementioned bank that sends [[black ops]] to find your stolen travelers checks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/97/97tinterbank.phtml |title=Interbank |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * ''I Know Why The Caged Bird Laughs'' — Promo for a new TV show featuring [[Maya Angelou]] (played by [[Maya Rudolph]]) pulling pranks on her circle of celebrity friends; the pranks include putting a pie on [[Morgan Freeman]]'s (Jay Pharoah) chair, taking the bottom out of Dr. [[Cornel West]]'s ([[Kenan Thompson]]) suitcase, and interrupting [[Stephen King]]'s (Bill Hader) book signing to tell him that his car has been towed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://screen.yahoo.com/maya-angelou-prank-show-000000680.html |title=Maya Angelou Prank Show |accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref> * iPhone — [[Fred Armisen]] plays a man who uses his iPhone to keep his relationship with his pregnant wife separate from his affair with a French-Canadian woman whom he loves more.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/19302/saturday-night-live-iphone-the-affair |title=Saturday Night Live iPhone the Affair |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> (In the NBC rebroadcasts, this was replaced with another iPhone ad, this time with Jason Sudeikis as a man who uses his iPhone to elude the police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/07/07diphone2.phtml |title=SNL Transcripts: Brian Williams: 11/03/07: iPhone II |publisher=Snltranscripts.jt.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-19}}</ref>) *i-sleepPRO — This ambient sleep aid that has settings for "[[white noise]]" and "black noise"; the latter includes thumping bass music, dialogue from [[Tyler Perry]] sitcoms and the movie ''[[Friday (1995 film)|Friday]]'', domestic arguments, and an old woman complaining about her foot pain. [[Jay Pharoah]] provides voice work for the device.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-rP0xn9PGHk ''SNL'': "i-SleepPRO"] on YouTube (accessed 7/27/2018)</ref> * ''I Was Not a Sucker for Saturday Night'' — [[Laraine Newman]] (as her recurring character Sherry) pitches a book about her risqué encounters with the male writers of ''Saturday Night Live''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75xsherry.phtml |title=I Was Not A Sucker For Saturday Night |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref>
== J == * J.J. Casuals – [[Jack Johnson (musician)|Jack Johnson]] ([[Andy Samberg]]) promotes shoes shaped like bare feet for those who are as casual as he is.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.popscreen.com/v/2R00/JJ-Casuals |title=JJ Casuals |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jamitol – parody of [[Geritol]] in which a husband ([[Chevy Chase]]) extols the virtues of the [[multivitamin]] that has kept his wife ([[Michael O'Donoghue]]) working to the point of exhaustion. "My wife. I think I'll stuff her!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75ajamitol.phtml |title=Jamitol |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75ejamitol.phtml |title=Jamitol |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jam Hawkers – carries the Smucker's slogan ("With a name like Smucker's, it has to be good!") to absurd extremes, promoting jams that taste so good that the manufacturers dare to give them horrible and disturbing names. Most members of the first-season cast appear as spokesmen, each trying to outdo the other on the "best" jam in the following order:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75qjam.phtml |title=Jam Hawkers |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> ** [[Jane Curtin]] – Fluckers: "It's got to be good!" ** [[Chevy Chase]] – Nose Hair: "You can imagine how good it must be... mm–mm!" ** [[Dan Aykroyd]] – Death Camp: "Just look for the barbed wire on the label!" ** [[John Belushi]] – Dog Vomit & Monkey Pus: "This stuff has got to be terrific!" ** [[Chevy Chase]] – Painful Rectal Itch: "The taste? (kisses fingers)" ** [[Dan Aykroyd]] – Mangled Baby Ducks: "Great jam! Beautiful jam!" ** [[John Belushi]] – 10,000 Nuns and Orphans (Jane: "What's so bad about that? John: They were all eaten by rats!") "Oh so good!" ** [[Garrett Morris]] then brings in a jar that's "So disgusting you can't say it on television!" * Jar Glove – In a parody of the black-and-white dramatizations of someone struggling to perform an everyday task without the use of the product being sold, a housewife ([[Kristen Wiig]]) accidentally kills her husband ([[Jason Sudeikis]]), resists arrest, is sentenced, goes to prison, plots and executes an escape, and hides out from prison guards—all because she struggled with opening the lid on a jar without benefit of the Jar Glove.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/34460/saturday-night-live-jar-glove |title=Saturday Night Live Jar Glove |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Javis Homer Security System – a commercial that begins as a diaper ad featuring a man ([[Will Ferrell]]) reminiscing about the first time he changed his baby's diaper. The baby's mother ([[Ana Gasteyer]]) enters the room, yelling, "Who the hell are you?!" and the man makes a frantic escape out the window while the mother cries and holds her baby in fear.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/99/99ajavis.phtml |title=Javis Home Security Systems |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jenson Mint – phony dollars and coins for rich people who want homeless panhandlers to leave them alone once and for all.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/98/98fjensonmint.phtml |title=Jenson Mint |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jewess Jeans – [[Gilda Radner]] models these jeans in this parody of [[Jordache]] jeans (and, to a lesser extent, [[Henry S. Levy and Sons|Levy's]] rye bread). The Levy's-like tag line advises that "no one has to be [[Jewish]]" to wear Jewess ("but it wouldn't hurt", Radner adds).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/61330/saturday-night-live-jewess-jeans |title=Saturday Night Live Jewess Jeans |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jiffy Express – When you forgot your package had to be at its destination yesterday, Jiffy says "We'll take the package... AND the blame" by [[Calendar date|back-dating]] packages and simulating shipping delays.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/285313/saturday-night-live-jiffy-express |title=Saturday Night Live Jiffy Express |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jiffy Pop [[Airbag|Air Bag]] – Eat [[popcorn]] while you're waiting for the [[ambulance]] to arrive.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/281951/saturday-night-live-jiffy-pop-airbag |title=Saturday Night Live Jiffy Pop Airbag |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * Jogger Motel – A parody of the commercials for [[Black Flag (insecticide)|Black Flag]] [[Roach Motel (insect trap)|Roach Motel]] roach traps. Its tagline read, "Joggers jog in, but they don't jog out".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/81/81djoggermotel.phtml |title=Jogger Motel |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> * ''Joe Dude'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://classicajays.tumblr.com/post/7865487325/this-is-the-joe-dude-sketch-from-the-jeff-gordon |title=Joe Dude |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> ''Joe Hetero'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/02/02ijoe1.phtml |title=Joe Hetero |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> ''Joe Caucasian'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/02/02ijoe2.phtml |title=Joe Caucasian |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> and ''Joe Not-a-Rapist''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/02/02ijoe3.phtml |title=Joe Not A Rapist |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> – promos for [[Fox Television Network|Fox]] reality shows based on ''[[Joe Millionaire]]'', where a bachelor tricks female contestants into thinking he (or in the case of "Joe Dude", she) is male, heterosexual, white, or not a rapist. * [[Jon Hamm]]'s John Ham – the actor promotes ham you can eat while sitting on the toilet, complete with a dispenser similar to that of toilet paper.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/jon-hamms-john-ham/788590/ |title=''Saturday Night Live'': Jon Hamm's John Ham |accessdate=2011-10-17}}</ref>
== K == * K-Put Price-Is-Rite Stamp Gun — a price-stamp gun that allows shoppers to freely alter the prices of various goods (particularly groceries) in their own favor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75egun.phtml |title=K-Put Price-Is-Rite Stamp Gun |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Kannon AE-1 — a camera "so simple, so advanced, even [[Stevie Wonder]] [as himself] can use it!" A spoof of [[Canon AE-1]] [[Single-lens reflex camera|SLR]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/kannon-camera/n9098 |title=''SNL'': Kannon AE-1 |accessdate=11 Sep 2018}}</ref> * ''Kate & Ali'' — a series of promos for a spoof of ''[[Kate & Allie]]''—only instead of two divorced women, it's screen legend [[Katharine Hepburn]] ([[Martin Short]]) sharing a domicile with boxing great [[Muhammad Ali]] ([[Billy Crystal]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/kate-and-ali/1351153|title="Kate & Ali" SNL sketch from NBC.com|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/274204/saturday-night-live-kate-and-ali |title=Saturday Night Live Kate and Ali |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * KCF Shredders — Lampoons fast food industry's marketing to kids, in this case with lettuce. "Now with [[How Stella Got Her Groove Back]] action figures!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/291068/saturday-night-live-kfc-shredders |title=Saturday Night Live KFC Shredders |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref> * Khool Toilet — Parroting the classic [[1984 (advertisement)|"1984" ad]] that introduced [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh computer]], complete with a sledgehammer-wielding protagonist (episode host [[Benedict Cumberbatch]]), this ad promotes the latest toilet fixture from the [[Kohler Co.]] that allows one to sit “the cool way” on a toilet—backwards, with your arms casually draped over the back, as opposed to the forward-facing style of old toilets [[Big Brother (Nineteen Eighty-Four)|Big Brother]] dictates the proletariat to use.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zOjtBmLrjho ''SNL'': "Khool Toilet"] on YouTube (accessed 10/13/2018)</ref> *''Kim's Fairytale Divorce'' — "Whoopsees, I got divorced!" So admits [[Kim Kardashian]] ([[Nasim Pedrad]]) in this promo for the latest [[E!]] special centered on the Karsashian family, this time making a glamorous event out of Kim's divorce from [[Chris Humphries]] ([[Andy Samberg]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-B-dg6hEEmA|title=The Kim Kardashian Fairytale Divorce Special on E! - SNL|first=|last=Saturday Night Live|date=27 September 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> * [[Kotex]] Classic — a very large [[sanitary napkin]] which includes a belt, and is clearly visible under a woman's clothing, very much like the sanitary napkins worn by women and girls of the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/284560/saturday-night-live-kotex-classic |title=Saturday Night Live Kotex Classic |accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref>
== L == * Lansford Brothers & Associates: Hangmen-At-Law – Businessman brothers ([[Will Forte]] and [[Bill Hader]]) offer professional Texas-style lynchings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/06/06klansford.phtml |title=Lansford Brothers and Associates Hangmen-at-Law |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * ''Law & Order: Parking Violations Unit'' – A promo for the latest addition to the ''[[Law & Order franchise|Law & Order]]'' franchise, this one centered on the police who investigate parking crimes and the district attorneys who prosecute the offenders challenging their tickets.<ref>[https://view.yahoo.com/show/saturday-night-live/clip/40035290/law-order-parking-violations-unit ''SNL'': ''Law & Order: Parking Violations Unit''] on Yahoo! View (accessed 7/19/2018)</ref> * Lemon Glow – an ex-biker chick ([[Molly Shannon]]) wistfully recalls her drugs-and-sex days while cleaning the middle-class home she's conned herself into.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/97/97clemonglow.phtml |title=Lemon Glow |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * Leland-Meyers Home Headache Test (HHt) – Home test designed to determine if one is really having a headache or not, requiring the tester to "draw a moderate amount" of one's own blood, place a drop on the test strip, and wait two hours. If the spot turns blue, you have a headache! Parody of home [[pregnancy test]]s featuring [[Kevin Nealon]] & [[Janeane Garofalo]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/94/94ahht.phtml |title=hht Home Headache Test |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * [[Levi Strauss & Co.|Levi's]] Wokes - sizeless (i.e. baggy), style-neutral (i.e. grayish brown), gender non-conforming denim jeans for a generation that defies labels.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=adPXDTvADD0 ''SNL'': "Levi's Wokes"] on YouTube (accessed 10/3/2017)</ref> * Lexon Paradox – Two automotive design teams produced two completely opposite cars (e.g., one was the most expensive car ever, the other the cheapest; one was the safest, the other designed to throw flaming victims hundreds of feet in a crash). In the end, the two were combined to create The Paradox.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/94/94bparadox.phtml |title=Lexon Paradox |accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> * Liberty Medical – [[Wilford Brimley]] (episode host [[John Goodman]]) begins his pitch for this medical supply delivery service by explaining how, with [[Diabetes mellitus|"dye-a-beetuss"]], he has to take extra care of his health, but continually qualifies, and admits to exaggerations, until by the end, he's described hiding a "food boner" over a delivery of $200 worth of pork ribs to his house, never having moved fast enough to sweat, and the fact that he may not even have diabetes—his doctor "just thinks I look like the kinda guy who ''would'' have it".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/01/01dliberty.phtml |title=Liberty Medical Insurance |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * Lil' General Fireworks — A manufacturer of [[fireworks]] promotes their product a family-friendly way turn any boring weekend into the 4th of July.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RaLLZ_x34zI ''SNL'': Lil' General Fireworks] on YouTube (accessed 7/11/2018)</ref> * Lil' Poundcake – A parody from season 37, of a doll that gives [[HPV]] vaccination shots to little girls. * [[Lincoln National Corporation|Lincoln Financial]] — Three spoofs of the [[investment]] company's "Get to know the future you" campaign, specifically an ad in which an airline passenger meets the future version of himself. In Ad #1, a man ([[Jason Sudeikis]]) has oral sex with his future self;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/287086/saturday-night-live-lincoln-financial-i |title=Saturday Night Live Lincoln Financial I |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> in Ad #2, another man ([[Bill Hader]]) is told by his future self that he's going to gain weight, go bankrupt, fly to Hawaii, and kill himself (but not before making out with him);<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/287087/saturday-night-live-lincoln-financial-ii |title=Saturday Night Live Lincoln Financial II |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> Ad #3 finds another man (guest [[Ben Stiller]]) mistaking a female passenger ([[Abby Elliott]]) for his transgender future self.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/287094/saturday-night-live-lincoln-financial-iii |title=Saturday Night Live Lincoln Financial III |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * [[Lincoln MKC]] – Episode host [[Jim Carrey]] lampoons [[Matthew McConaughey]]'s exisential pitchwork for [[Lincoln Motor Company|Lincoln's]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover utility vehicle]] in this trio of ads. McConaughey gets so lost in his deep thoughts that in the third ad, he drives right through an [[Allstate]] commercial parody, hitting Allstate pitchman [[Dennis Haysbert]] ([[Keenan Thompson]]) in the process. Carrey would later reprise this spoof in the ''Celebrity Jeopardy'' sketch in ''SNL''{{'}}s 40th Anniversary Special.<ref>[https://screen.yahoo.com/video-search/lincoln-ads-071111377.html Lincoln Ads parody] from Yahoo! Screen (accessed 2/16/2015)</ref> * Little Brothers – An ad similar in vein to [[Peyton Manning]]'s "United Way" commercial; here, Manning's younger brother [[Eli Manning|Eli]] is ambassador of a mentoring program for young boys who need a strong, male role model in their lives — and someone to beat up their mean older brothers (one of which, played by [[Andy Samberg]], is locked in the trunk of a car and mistakenly referred to as "Peyton"). The commercial ends with the tag line "Little Brothers: Because the time of reckoning is now at hand", followed by Eli and his young charges laughing maniacally.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/358346/saturday-night-live-little-brothers |title=Saturday Night Live Little Brothers |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * Litter Critters – [[Cheri Oteri]] appears in this sketch about a kit that allows children to take their cat's fecal waste and mold it into fun figurines. "♪♫ When you hear a scratch, here comes a batch — It's time for Litter Critters! ♪♫"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2325/saturday-night-live-litter-critters |title=Saturday Night Live Litter Critters |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * Little Chocolate Donuts — "[[decathlon]] champion [[John Belushi]]" promotes "The Donuts of Champions" in this parody of [[Caitlyn Jenner|Bruce Jenner's]]{{efn|Bruce Jenner is now known as Caitlyn Jenner due to [[gender transition]] in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leibovitz|first=Annie|title=Introducing Caitlyn Jenner|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/06/caitlyn-jenner-bruce-cover-annie-leibovitz/|work=Vanity Fair|date=June 1, 2015|accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref> }} pitch work for [[Wheaties]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/2345/saturday-night-live-little-chocolate-donuts |title=Saturday Night Live Little Chocolate Donuts |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * Long White Beard – "Let 'em know you've been waiting." Featured various cast members and actors wearing obviously fake, long, white beards in situations where someone has kept them waiting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/197249/saturday-night-live-long-white-beard |title=Saturday Night Live Long White Beard |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * ''The Looker'' — [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT's]] newest procedural drama stars [[Penny Marshall]] ([[Fred Armisen]]) as a police interrogator who gets suspects to sign confessions simply by staring at them for long periods of time.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GmnMGXXX-Hs ''TNT'': "The Looker"] on YouTube (accessed 7/27/2018)</ref> * Loose Bear – a [[hallucinogenic]] [[laxative]] that makes you dream you're being chased in the woods by a hungry [[bear]], thus "scaring the crap out of you".<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/loose-bear/2872709 |title=Loose Bear |accessdate=11 Sep 2018}}</ref> * Lori Davis Hair Spray Exciting Hold – Listed in the ''SNL'' sketch records as "Focus on Beauty II", this [[infomercial]] spoof promotes an environmentally conscious hair spray with no alcohol in it, featuring episode host [[Christina Applegate]] as [[Cher]], [[Chris Farley]] as Lori Davis, and Phil Hartman as "Brad in the Lab".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/4172/saturday-night-live-focus-on-beauty-ii |title=Saturday Night Live Focus on Beauty II |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * The Love Toilet – [[Victoria Jackson]] & [[Kevin Nealon]] share the most intimate moment of them all... on a single-based toilet with two seats, placed so that the seated users can face each other. "Because when you're in love, even five minutes apart can seem like an eternity."<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/61322/saturday-night-live-the-love-toilet |title=Saturday Night Live The Love Toilet |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * The Lung Brush – used every night by heavy smoker [[Chris Farley]] to remove quarts of tar from his lungs before going to bed with wife [[Victoria Jackson]] ("Did you forget to brush?"). Former [[NFL]] quarterback [[Ken Stabler]] makes a celebrity endorsement cameo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/91/91elungbrush.phtml |title=Lung Brush |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> * Lux 420 SL – [[Cliff Robertson]], in a deadpan cameo, promotes the car that caters to insane people; designed by such notables as [[Nostradamus]], its features include an in-console sink for compulsive hand-washing and enough trunk space to hold copious vials of one's own urine. The tagline: "There's a radio in my fingernail...CAR!!"<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/lux-420sl/n10918 |title=''SNL'': "Lux 420SL" |accessdate=11 Sep 2018}}</ref>
== M == * Mack North — Even though he handily defeated opponent Fred Peete ([[Chris Parnell]]) in the 6th district election, North ([[Will Ferrell]]) continues his campaign against him with a trio of attack ads, all in an effort to rub his victory in Peete's face.<ref>[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/snl-sketch-from-1998-foreshadows-trumps-obsession-with-hillary_us_59f9ed32e4b046017fb06a61 "‘SNL’ Sketch From 1998 Foreshadows Trump’s Obsession With Hillary,"] from ''Huffington Post'', 11/1/2017</ref> * Magic Mouth — a device which is inserted into the [[rectum]] and converts [[flatulence]] into "polished expressions" (e.g. "Did you see ''[[Charlie Rose]]'' last night?").<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0v6sgTj9uMI ''SNL'': Magic Mouth] on YouTube (accessed 6/14/2018)</ref> * MartinSheen – a hair spray which consisted of guest [[Martin Sheen]] sipping water from a paper cup and spitting it on Jane Curtin's hair as she pitched the product, pausing occasionally to nod in agreement with her statements (e.g. "MartinSheen is eco-friendly. You wouldn't dream of hurting the environment, would you?").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xaqiv1_martin-sheen-hairspray-the-snl-comm_fun |title=Martin Sheen Hairspray – The SNL commercial |accessdate=24 July 2012}}</ref> * Mary-Kate & Ashley Perfume – The perfume that fits your mood, whether you're an [[Ashley Olsen|Ashley]] or a [[Mary-Kate Olsen|Mary-Kate]]. A female voice-over whispers "Ashley" to one activity and "Mary-Kate" to one in contrast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cookiedough619.buzznet.com/user/video/20061/olsen-twins-saturday-night-live/ |title=The Olsen Twins Saturday Night Live Skit (Fragerance) |accessdate=24 July 2012}}</ref> *[[Match.com]] — This ad for the dating website features various female members talking about the man they hope to find... and [[Martha Stewart]] ([[Kate McKinnon]]), who just wants "a successful man... for intercourse."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tBRCcxLbt0s ''SNL'': Martha Stewart for Match.com] on YouTube (accessed 7/11/2018)</ref> * [[Maya Angelou]] — [[David Alan Grier]], in his 1997 turn as episode host, mimics the acclaimed poet and her flowery, emotional, hyperbolic prose in a trio of ads, including: ** [[Butterfinger]] candy ("Glad mantle of golden chocolaty hope upon my breast.")<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/maya-angelou-for-butterfinger/n10938?snl=1 ''SNL'': "Maya Angelou for Butterfingers,"] on NBC.com (accessed 1/18/2018)</ref> ** [[Froot Loops]] ("Fruity loops, Fruit Loopies, swimming in the churning, frothy mother sea of milk.")<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/maya-angelou-for-froot-loops/n10940 |title=''Saturday Night Live'' "Maya Angelou for Froot Loops" |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> ** [[Pennzoil]] ("O! Magic shining ewer of liquid ball bearings.")<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/maya-angelou-for-pennzoil/n10942?snl=1 ''SNL'': "Maya Angelou for Pennzoil"] on NBC.com (accessed 1/18/2018)</ref> * Maybelline For Men – Finally, cosmetics for guys.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/19298 |title=Saturday Night Live Maybelline Men |accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> * McIntosh Jr. – an elementary-school cafeteria parody of early [[Macintosh computer]] ads. "McIntosh Jr.: The Power to Crush the Other Kids!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://videosift.com/video/MacIntosh-Jr-The-power-to-CRUSH-the-other-kids-SNL-skit |title=MacIntosh Jr, The power to CRUSH the other kids – SNL skit |accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> * McIntosh Post-It Notes (sic) – parody of the [[Apple Newton]] MessagePad.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Q-BH8j06pM |title=snl macintosh post it notes |accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> * Mega Mart — In this 2010 ad, an amped-up [[Bobby Moynihan]] promotes this big-box retailer's "12-Minute Madness" sale on [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]], where a "savings stampede" will be assured, thanks to freshly waxed floors ("Slide into savings!"), no security guards, box cutters for every customer (to remove overstocked items from the back of the store), and an exclusive offer of a previously unreleased [[Harry Potter]] book.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iB5hYK0-__k ''SNL'': "Black Friday"] on YouTube (accessed 7/20/2018)</ref> * Me-Harmony.com – a 2005 [[parody]] of [[eHarmony]] promotes a [[matchmaking]] [[website]] for [[narcissism|narcissists]]. Various ''SNL'' castmembers have dual roles as both the happy Me-Harmony client and, in drag, their perfect mate. The ad also promotes its sister service, the gay matchmaking site He-Harmony.com.<ref>[http://www.hulu.com/watch/282844 Me-Harmony.com] on Hulu, accessed 6/18/2012</ref> * Mel's Char Palace – Mel ([[Dan Aykroyd]]), with help from a saw-wielding "Mrs. Mel" ([[Gilda Radner]]), promotes his steakhouse on "[[New Jersey Route 17|Route 17]], [[Paramus, New Jersey|Paramus]]" where diners select their own steer, cuts and portions ("You stun it, you cut it, you charbroil it").<ref>{{cite web |url=https://screen.yahoo.com/mels-char-palace-000000244.html |title=Saturday Night Live Mel's Char Palace |accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://screen.yahoo.com/mels-char-palace-2-000000885.html |title=Saturday Night Live Mel's Char Palace (version 2) |accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref> * Mercury Mistress – A spoof of luxury-car ads, this ad promotes "a car so sexy, you'll just want to have sex with it" (because a rubber [[vagina]] is hidden behind its license plate).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Qe_-MrKaoU |title=SNL Mercury Mistress commercial 1998 FULL VERSION (1.34 min) |accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> * Metrocard – a [[credit card]] ad starring [[Roseanne Barr]] as a sassy customer service representative and [[Phil Hartman]] as a business traveler in need of assistance. Says Barr: "Yeah, like I've got nothing better to do than to sit around and listen to him bitch!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/metrocard/1353393/ |title=Saturday Night Live Metrocard |accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> * Michael Phelps Diet – Olympic gold medalist [[Michael Phelps]] shows his "eat whatever you want, and as much as you want" diet which is almost certainly fatal to anyone who isn't an Olympic athlete because of its high caloric count (12,000 calories, which is the actual number of calories Michael Phelps was required to eat while training).
