{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{use American English|date=March 2017}} {{merge|Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products|discuss=Talk:Walt Disney Parks and Resorts#Merger proposal|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Worldwide, Inc. | logo = Walt Disney Parks and Resorts logo.svg | type = Subsidiary | fate = Merged with [[Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media]] | successor = [[Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1971|04|01}} | defunct = {{End date|2018|3|14}} | location_city = [[Orlando, Florida]]{{cite web |title=Company Overview of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts U.S., Inc |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=4159864 |website=Bloomberg}} | location_country = United States | key_people = Bob Chapek (Chairman) | industry = Travel | services = {{flatlist| *Theme parks *Hotel lodging *Cruises *Timeshares *Guided tours *Travel packages *Attraction design}} | subsid = {{unbulleted list|[[Walt Disney Imagineering|Walt Disney Imagineering Research & Development, Inc.]]|[[Walt Disney World|Walt Disney Parks and Resorts U.S., Inc.]]|[[Euro Disney S.C.A.|Euro Disney Investments, Inc.]]|Disneyland International}} | divisions = [[Disneyland Resort]] | num_employees = 130,000 (2015){{cite news|last1=Barnes|first1=Brooks|title=Thomas Staggs: Disney’s Heir, Apparently|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/26/business/media/thomas-staggs-disneys-heir-apparently.html|accessdate=April 26, 2015|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=April 26, 2015|location=New York|page=BU1}} | parent = [[The Walt Disney Company]] | homepage = {{URL|http://disneyparks.disney.go.com}}
{{URL|aboutdisneyparks.com|corporate}} }} '''Walt Disney Parks and Resorts''', officially '''Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Worldwide, Inc.''' and informally known as '''Disney Parks''', was one of [[The Walt Disney Company]]'s four major business segments and a subsidiary.{{cite web|title=Detail by Entity Name: Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Worldwide, Inc.|url=http://search.sunbiz.org/Inquiry/CorporationSearch/SearchResultDetail?inquirytype=EntityName&directionType=ForwardList&searchNameOrder=WALTDISNEYPARKSRESORTSWORLDWID%20F090000012040&aggregateId=forp-f09000001204-dfbb7cc6-7dee-4d8b-bbef-3244c551d808&searchTerm=Walt%20Disney%20Parks%20and%20Resorts%20Worldwide&listNameOrder=WALTDISNEYPARKSRESORTSWORLDWID%20F090000012040|website=SunBiz.org|publisher=Florida Department of State Division of Corporations|accessdate=October 12, 2015}} It was founded in 1971, following the opening of [[Magic Kingdom]] at [[Walt Disney World]] in Florida. Originally, the company was known as '''Walt Disney Outdoor Recreation Division''' and later as '''Walt Disney Attractions'''. The chairman of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts was Bob Chapek, formerly president of [[Disney Consumer Products]]. Chapek reports to Disney CEO [[Bob Iger]].{{cite news|last1=Palmeri|first1=Christopher|title=Disney's Parks Chief Emerges as Contender to Succeed Iger|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-27/disney-s-parks-chief-emerges-as-strong-contender-to-succeed-iger?cmpId=flipboard|accessdate=November 28, 2017|work=Bloomberg.com|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=November 27, 2017}} In 2016, the company's theme parks hosted over 140.4 million guests, making Disney Parks the world's most visited theme park company worldwide,{{Cite web|title=TEA/AECOM 2016 Theme Index and Museum Index: The Global Attractions Attendance Report|url=http://www.teaconnect.org/images/files/TEA_235_103719_170601.pdf|publisher=''[[Themed Entertainment Association|TEA]]/[[AECOM]]''|date=2017|p=9|accessdate=June 2, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170602201150/http://www.teaconnect.org/images/files/TEA_235_103719_170601.pdf|archivedate=June 2, 2017}} with United Kingdom-based [[Merlin Entertainments]] coming in second. It is by far Disney's largest business segment according to employee headcount, with approximately 130,000 of the company's 180,000 employees as of 2015.{{cite web|url=http://thewaltdisneycompany.com/sites/default/files/reports/fy14-form-10k.pdf|title=Form 10-K, U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, by the Walt Disney Company for the Fiscal Year Ended September 27, 2014|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|accessdate=November 23, 2014|date=November 19, 2014|page=1|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217131710/http://thewaltdisneycompany.com/sites/default/files/reports/fy14-form-10k.pdf|archivedate=December 17, 2014|df=mdy-all}} In March 2018, Parks and Resorts was merged with [[Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media]] to form [[Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products]]. ==Background== {{main|Disneyland, Inc.}} In 1949, [[Ice Capades]] added a Disney segment to its performances. Costumes from those shows were used at the opening of Disneyland in 1955 with some performers hired away for Disney.{{cite news|last1=Korkis|first1=Jim|title=Wednesdays with Wade: 25 years of "Disney on Ice"|url=http://jimhillmedia.com/alumni1/b/wade_sampson/archive/2005/09/14/1278.aspx|accessdate=July 30, 2015|work=JimHillMedia|date=September 13, 2005}} Originally, entry into the theme park and travel business was a side project of Walt Disney himself. As the Disneylandia project started to become a reality, [[The Walt Disney Company|Walt Disney Productions]] at Walt's request set up Disneyland, Inc. (DLI) in 1951 and agreed to a design deal in March 1953 with [[Retlaw Enterprises|WED Enterprises (WED)]], [[Walt Disney|Walt]]'s personal corporation, which then included what would now be called [[Walt Disney Imagineering|Disney Imagineering]].{{cite book|last1=Aberdeen|first1=J. A.|title=Hollywood Renegades|date=2000|publisher=Cobblestone Entertainment |isbn=1-890110-24-8 |url=http://www.cobbles.com/simpp_archive/simpp_1954disneyland.htm |accessdate=May 5, 2015|chapter=Disneyland}}{{cite book|last1=Thomas |first1=Bob |title=Building a Company - Roy O. Disney and the Creation of an Entertainment Empire|date=1998|page=254|accessdate=April 7, 2015}} *{{cite book|last1=Gabler|first1=Neal|title=Walt Disney - The Triumph of the American Imagination|date=2006|page=493}} With the WED concept designs and prospectus for Disneylandia, Roy Disney in September 1953 met with TV networks in a deal for Disney-produced TV show and Disneyland investment. [[American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres]] (AB-PT) agreed to the Disneyland, Inc. investment. Joining AB-PT as Disneyland investors were [[Walt Disney Productions]] (WDP), [[Western Publishing]] and [[Walt Disney]].{{cite book|last1=Thomas|first1=Bob|title=Walt Disney - An American Original|date=1994|page=222}} Walt Disney Productions had the option to repurchase the Walt Disney, WED and Western Publishing shares (31%) by May 1, 1959, for $562,500.{{cite news|title=Disneyland Tabs $2.29 Per Capita; See Small Net First Yr.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yB4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=Walt+Disney+Productions+Disneyland,+Inc.+option&source=bl&ots=0NOMFq8DpO&sig=eQQINoEQqlhCBUd2kikDffo7G3U&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qi5JVZ2xF4uYsAWrloCQDw&ved=0CB8Q6AEwATge#v=onepage&q=Walt%20Disney%20Productions%20Disneyland%2C%20Inc.%20option&f=false|accessdate=May 6, 2015|work=Billboard|date=January 28, 1956|page=69}} With a need for the [[Disneyland Hotel (California)|Disneyland Hotel]] nearby and no funding available for Disney to build it, Walt Disney approached [[Jack Wrather]] to build the hotel who agreed.{{cite news|last1=Kimler|first1=Forest|title=Jack Built More Than a House|url=http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_OYARMoeQUr4/TH_wXKWs_pI/AAAAAAAABnU/XnEcgWwEtwk/s1600/1978+newspaper+2aa.JPG |accessdate=August 28, 2015 |work=Orange County Register|date=September 11, 1978}} [[Disneyland]], changed from Disneylandia, was announced in {{dts|1954|4}} by Walt to be opened in {{dts|1955|7}}.Walt Disney, by Jim Fanning, 1994. Page 100.Walt Disney - Hollywood's Dark Prince, by Marc Eliot, 1993. Page 223. On {{dts|1955|7|17}}, the Disneyland park with five themed "lands" containing eighteen attractions with double the expected guests.Walt Disney, by Jim Fanning, 1994. Page 102. WED owned [[Disneyland Railroad|Santa Fe & Disneyland Railroad]] opened, too.{{cite news|last=Peltz|first=James F.|title=The Wonderful World of Disney's Other Firm : Entertainment: Walt Disney created a separate company for his family. Retlaw Enterprises Inc. is now worth hundreds of millions.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-10-02/business/fi-1834_1_walt-disney|accessdate=July 19, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=October 2, 1990}} On {{dts|1957|6|29}}, Disney Production exercised its options to purchase all but AB-PT's common stock outstanding. This allowed WDP to consolidate DLI into its 1957 annual accounting statements adding four months worth of net profits, $511K.{{cite news|title=Disneyland Draws 4,200,000; Parent Firm Buys More Stock|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ayEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA86|accessdate=May 6, 2015|work=Billboard|date=January 13, 1958}} In June 1960, Walt Disney Productions completed the purchase of AB-PT's share of the company for nearly $7.5 million and its TV contract, and the theme park became a fully owned subsidiary of Walt Disney Productions.{{cite book|last1=Thomas|first1=Bob |title=Walt Disney - An American Original |date=1994|page=286}} The first [[Audio-Animatronics|Audio-Animatronic]] attraction, [[Walt Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room]], opened at [[Disneyland]] in 1963.{{cite book |first=Richard W. |last=Kroon |title=A/V A to Z: An Encyclopedic Dictionary of Media, Entertainment and Other Audiovisual Terms |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HjmNAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA64 |year=2014 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0-7864-5740-3 |page=64}} ==History== Beginning in 1958 with the contracting of Economics Research Associates (ERA) to find a location for another Disney resort, Disney Productions moved beyond a single park. ERA recommended Florida; another study in 1961 named [[Ocala, Florida|Ocala]] or [[Orlando]] in Florida as possible locations. In {{dts|1963|11}}, Walt Disney made a trip to Florida for final site selection.Walt Disney - An American Original, by Bob Thomas, 1994.:333, 334 In 1962, Disney Productions purchased [[Celebrity Sports Center]] (opened on September 17, 1960, in Denver, Colorado) from its owners, including Walt Disney, [[Art Linkletter]], and [[John Payne (actor)|John Payne]], to use as a staff training center for its second resort.{{cite web|title=Celebrity Sports Center|url=https://d23.com/a-to-z/celebrity-sports-center/|website=D23.com|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|accessdate=October 6, 2015}} In 1963, Roy made plans to buy from {{convert|5,000|to|10,000|acre}}, which was carried out in 1964, amassing {{convert|27,443|acre}} by {{dts|1965|10}}.Building a Company - Roy O. Disney and the Creation of an Entertainment Empire, by Bob Thomas, 1998. Pages 278, 279, 281-282.Walt Disney - An American Original, by Bob Thomas, 1994. Page 337. Plans for the Florida project that would eventually become [[Walt Disney World]] were announced to the public in {{dts|1965|11}}. Legislation forming the [[Reedy Creek Improvement District]] was signed into law by Florida Governor [[Claude R. Kirk, Jr.]] on May 12, 1967, allowing Disney to build the infrastructure for the second park.{{cite book|last1=Thomas |first1=Bob|title=Walt Disney - An American Original|date=1994|accessdate=September 21, 2015|page=357}} Ground breaking followed for the future Reedy Creek park on May 30.{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Dave|last2=Clark|first2=Steven|title=Disney - The First 100 Years|date=2002|page=103|edition=updated|accessdate=September 21, 2015}} In Roy O. Disney's last act as CEO in 1968, he officially named the second park [[Walt Disney World]].:357 Disneyland International was incorporated on {{dts|1961|11|20}}.{{cite web|title=Business Entity Detail: Disneyland International (C0423655; must search on name)|url=http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/|website=California Department of State|accessdate=September 24, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315010639/http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/|archive-date=March 15, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The next year, [[The Oriental Land Company]] contacted Disney about building a theme park.{{cite news|title=Disneyland in Tokyo Is a 10-Year Hit|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-04-12/business/fi-45190_1_tokyo-disneyland|accessdate=August 20, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=Associated Press|date=April 12, 1994}} In {{dts|1959}}, the WED-owned [[Disneyland Monorail System|Disneyland-Alweg Monorail System]] was installed at Disneyland.{{cite news|title=Disneyland: A Chronology|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-05-09/news/mn-2210_1_walt-disney| accessdate=September 23, 2015 |work=Los Angeles Times| date=May 9, 1991}} Disneyland's first new themed land, New Orleans Square, opened in {{dts|1966}}. Tomorrowland was revamped in 1967 with seven new attractions. The design and architectural group and the WED Enterprise name was purchased from Walt's corporation, renamed as Retlaw Enterprise. Disney expanded into attractions at the [[1964 New York World's Fair]] with [[It's a Small World]] and costumed character appearances. When the characters proved a hit at the 1964 World's Fair, Walt wanted another outlet for "live" characters; thus, Disneyland put on ''Disney on Parade'', a self-produced live arena show starting in 1969.{{cite news|title=Live Disney Characters in Traveling Arena Show|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rDwwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ySoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3905%2C4281044|accessdate=July 30, 2015|work=The News and the Eastern Townships Advocate|issue=Vol. 123 No. 45|publisher=E.R. Smith Co. Ltd.|date=September 17, 1970|location=St. Johns, PQ|pages=2, 3}} Small World and its famous song lasted two years at the fair; it was then moved to Disneyland as an expanded major attraction in 1966 and later duplicated in the other Disney theme parks.{{cite news|last1=Shaw Brown|first1=Genevieve|title=It's a Small World: 9 Little-Known Facts|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Travel/disneys-small-world-facts/story?id=22990670|accessdate=August 26, 2015|work=Good Morning America|publisher=ABC News|date=March 21, 2014}} In 1965, Walt Disney won a bid with the [[US Forest Service]] to develop [[Mineral King]] as a ski resort. The [[Sierra Club]] sued in {{dts|1969|6}} to stop the development, which was granted by the federal district judge. The Forest Service appealed and won at the appeal and the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court ruling left open to the Club the possibility of refiling. In the next round of lawsuits, the same district judge blocked the redevelopment. The injunction and the passage of the [[National Environmental Policy Act]] led to Disney backing out.{{cite news |url=http://www.hcn.org/wotr/the-saga-of-mineral-king |title=The saga of Mineral King |date=February 2, 2009 |newspaper=High Country News |accessdate=September 12, 2009}} $40 million worth of Walt Disney Productions Convertible [[Debenture]]s were sold in {{dts|1968|1}} to fund Disney World (WDW). The next year in February, an agreement was made with multiple labor unions, in which the unions exchanged the right to strike for regular pay increases during the first building phase.{{cite news|work=U.S. News & World Report|last1=Cooper|first1=M|last2=Friedman|first2=D|title=Empire of the Sun|date=May 28, 1990|page=47}} By 1971, chairman of the Park Operations Committee and vice president of park operations Dick Nunis was appointed executive vice president of Disneyland and Walt Disney World.{{cite web|title=Disney Legend: Dick Nunis|url=https://d23.com/walt-disney-legend/dick-nunis/|website=d23|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|accessdate=October 7, 2015}} [[Walt Disney World]] began operation on {{dts|1971|10|1}}, with the [[Magic Kingdom]] park at a cost of $400 million. The Magic Kingdom had six themed lands: Main Street, Adventureland, Fantasyland, Frontierland, Liberty Square, and Tomorrowland.{{cite book|title=Birnbaum's Walt Disney World 1997|date=1996|publisher=Hearst Business Publishing|page=15|accessdate=September 22, 2015}} Additionally, Disney's Fort Wilderness Resort campground and two hotels, Disney's Contemporary Resort and Disney's Polynesian Village Resort, also opened.{{cite book| last1=Smith|first1=Dave |title=Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia|date=1996|accessdate=September 22, 2015|page=103,191,397}} Disneyland expanded in 1972 with a seventh themed land, [[Bear Country (Disneyland)|Bear Country]], replacing the Indian Village of Frontierland, and later renamed Critter Country. In 1979, the Disneyland crafts and maintenance union workers went on strike for 15 days, at first rejecting and then accepting the park's contract. [[Space Mountain (Disneyland)|Space Mountain]] opens at Disneyland in 1977. Two more hotels opened in 1973 at Walt Disney World: the Golf Resort{{cite web|title=Disney Inn, The|url=https://d23.com/a-to-z/disney-inn-the/|website=D23: Disney A to Z|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|accessdate=September 23, 2015}} and the Gold Resort;{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Dave|title=Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia|date=1996|page=209}} Disney's Village Resort hotel opened in 1974.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} Disney opened the Buena Vista Club golf club in Lake Buena Vista on {{dts|1974|11|22}}.{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Dave|title=Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia|date=1996|accessdate=September 24, 2015}}:71 [[Disney Springs|Lake Buena Vista Village]], the shopping area, opened on {{dts|1975|3|22}} and was renamed Walt Disney World Village in 1977.{{cite web |last1=Smith |first1=Dave |title=Downtown Disney Marketplace |url=https://d23.com/a-to-z/downtown-disney-marketplace/|website=D23: Disney A to Z|publisher=Walt Disney Company|accessdate=September 24, 2015}}:280 Celebrity Sports Center, Disney World's training center, was sold on March 29, 1979. At Walt Disney World, the Treasure Island nature preserve pens opened on April 8, 1974,Disney A to Z - The Updated Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1998.:569 renamed Discovery Island in 1977.:126 On {{dts|1975|7|1}}, the [[WEDway PeopleMover]] opened in the Magic Kingdom's Tomorrowland.Disney Magazine, Summer 1999. Page 85. The first water park, [[Disney's River Country|River Country]], opened on {{dts|1976|6|20}} at Disney World.Birnbaum's Walt Disney World 1997, by Hearst Business Publishing, 1996.:22 [[Epcot|EPCOT]] Center's groundbreaking occurred at Walt Disney World in May 1979.Walt Disney World, by The Walt Disney Company, 1994?. In 1979, [[Oriental Land]] and Disney agreed to build a Japanese theme park. [[Tokyo Disneyland]] opened on {{dts|1983|4|15}} on {{convert|200|acre|sigfig=1}} in [[Urayasu, Chiba]], Japan.{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Greg|title=Disney Plans Aquatic Park in Tokyo|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-11-08/business/fi-711_1_tokyo-disneysea|accessdate=August 20, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 8, 1995}} ===Walt Disney Outdoor Recreation Division=== With the June 3, 1980, retirement of [[Donn Tatum]] as Walt Disney Productions' Chairman and CEO, three divisions were formed, including the Walt Disney Outdoor Recreation Division, of which Nunis was named division president.The New York Times, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1980.htm June 4, 1980]. Page D1. Disneyland started using [[Company scrip|Disney Dollars]] on May 5, 1987,Canadian Coin News, July 21, 1987, Volume 25, Number 6. Page 2. while Walt Disney World parks started with Epcot on October 2.Canadian Coin News, October 27, 1987, Volume 25, Number 13. Page 1. A renegotiated Disneyland Japan royalty agreement in April 1988 by Chief Financial Officer [[Gary L. Wilson]] netted Disney US$723 million in cash in exchange for lower royalty payments.Forbes, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1988.htm March 6, 1989], Volume 143. Page 42. The steam railroad and monorail at Disneyland were purchased from [[Retlaw Enterprises]], formerly WED Enterprises, in 1982. Bear Country was renamed [[Critter Country]] on November 23, 1988.''Disneyland: Then, Now, and Forever'', by Bruce Gordon and Tim O'Day, 2005. Page 99. [[Tishman Realty & Construction|Tishman Company]]'s plans for two Walt Disney World hotels were rejected by new CEO [[Michael Eisner]] on September 30, 1984, marking a change in Disney architecture. New plans for the Dolphin and Swan hotels were submitted by Michael Graves in July 1986;Building a Dream - The Art of Disney Architecture, by Beth Dunlop, 1996. Pages 63,66. ground breaking took place on January 28, 1988.The New York Times, January 28, 1988. Page C1. The first non-Disney owned hotel, Pickett Suite Resort, opened in [[Disney Springs|Disney World Village]] on March 15, 1987.Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1996. Page 387. On June 1, 1982, the Walt Disney World monorail line was extended to EPCOT Center from the Ticket and Transportation Center.:338 The EPCOT Center theme park opened on October 1, 1982, at a building cost of US$1.2 billion, with two areas, [[Epcot#Future World|Future World]] and [[World Showcase]].Walt Disney - Hollywood's Dark Prince, by Marc Eliot, 1993.:272 Plans for a Hollywood-style theme park were announced in April 1985 for the Walt Disney World resort at a project cost of US$300 million.Prince of the Magic Kingdom, by Joe Flower, 1991. In April 1985, Disney signed a licensing agreement with [[MGM]], giving Disney the right to use the MGM name, logo and movie library for this third park.{{cite web|last1=Weiss|first1=Werner|title=Disney-MGM Studios: The End of the MGM Name|url=http://www.yesterland.com/mgm-end.html|website=Yesterland.com|publisher=|accessdate=October 7, 2015}} sources: *{{cite book|last1=Eisner|first1=Michael|title=Work in Progress|date=1998}} *{{cite book|last1=Grover|first1=Ron|title=The Disney Touch|date=1991}} Construction of the [[Disney's Hollywood Studios|Disney-MGM Studios]] theme park began in 1986.Walt Disney World - 20 Magical Years, by the Walt Disney Company, 1991/2?. Disney-MGM Studios opened on May 1, 1989,Page D5. The New York Times, May 1, 1989, Volume 138, Number 47857. along with a Pleasure Island entertainment area;Birnbaum's Walt Disney World 1997, by Hearst Business Publishing, 1996. Page 18. its second water park, [[Disney's Typhoon Lagoon]], opened on June 1.Orlando Attractions, Summer 2009. Page 33. In 1983, Walt Disney World Village's name was changed to the Disney Village Marketplace.Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1996. Page 132. A new themed area, Mickey's Birthdayland, opened in the Magic Kingdom near Fantasyland on June 18, 1988.Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1996. Page 324. In 1987, Disney and [[Ron Brierley]]'s Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., already a 28% owner of the [[Jack Wrather|Wrather Corporation]], agreed to purchase the remaining Wrather Corporation stock with a 50% share each.{{cite news|last1=Berg|first1=Eric N.|title=Company News; Wrather Accepts $21-a-Share Offer|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/business/company-news-wrather-accepts-21-a-share-offer.html|accessdate=August 27, 2015|work=New York Times|date=September 29, 1987}}{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=COMPANY NEWS; Disney Buys Stake|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/30/business/company-news-disney-buys-stake.html|accessdate=August 27, 2015|work=New York Times|date=March 30, 1988}} Wrather Corporation owned the [[Disneyland Hotel (California)|Disneyland Hotel]] and operated the [[RMS Queen Mary|Queen Mary]] and [[Hughes H-4 Hercules|Spruce Goose]] tourist attractions. In March 1988, Disney purchased Industrial Equity's half of Wrather Corporation. In 1985, [[Premier Cruise Line]] became the licensed partner cruise line with Disney. This allowed Disney characters on their ships and combined cruise, hotel, and theme park packages.{{cite news|last1=Fritscher|first1=Lisa|title=How Disney Cruises Started|url=http://traveltips.usatoday.com/disney-cruises-started-17319.html|accessdate=October 8, 2015|work=USA Today|agency=Demand Media|publisher=Gannett Satellite Information Network, Inc.}} ===Walt Disney Attractions=== The Walt Disney Outdoor Recreation Division was incorporated as Walt Disney Attractions, Inc. on August 10, 1989.{{cite web|title=Detail by Entity Name: Walt Disney Attractions, Incorporated |url= http://search.sunbiz.org/Inquiry/CorporationSearch/SearchResultDetail?inquirytype=EntityName&directionType=PreviousList&searchNameOrder=WALTDISNEYATTRACTIONS%20P255770&aggregateId=forp-p25577-93b956e8-76e8-42c2-b789-99a8528d7053&searchTerm=Walt%20Disney%20Parks%20and%20Resorts%20Worldwide&listNameOrder=WALTDIESINGASSOCIATES%20K475700 |website=SunBiz.org |publisher=Florida Department of State Division of Corporations|accessdate=October 12, 2015}} In January 1990, Disney CEO Eisner announced plans to expand both Disneyland (by 20% in 10 years)The New York Times, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1990.htm January 13, 1990]. Page 37. and Disney World (WDW). The plan would have WDW add another theme park and 16 new attractions in Disney-MGM Studios.The New York Times, January 16, 1990. Page D8. Disney and [[The Coca-Cola Company]] agreed to a 15-year marketing contract on January 25: Coca-Cola products would be exclusive in Disney theme parks, and Coca-Cola would use some Disney characters in their ads.The New York Times, January 26, 1990. Page D4. On March 16, 1990, Attractions president Nunis announced a 25-year plan for a {{convert|4400|acre|adj=on}} development in [[Osceola, Florida]], with homes, shopping malls and industrial buildings.The New York Times, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1990.htm March 17, 1990]. Page 37. In 1990, the possibility of a West Coast version of Epcot Center was placed in development.Business Week, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1990.htm January 29, 2001]. Page 58. This was announced as [[WestCOT]] in 1991, to be placed at the Disneyland Resort. On July 31, 1990, a new {{convert|350|acre|adj=on}} ocean-themed park and resort, Port Disney, was announced for Long Beach. Port was to have a cruise-ship terminal, five hotels, restaurants, and shopping area, costing $2 billion to build.The New York Times, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1990jul.htm August 1, 1990]. Page D4. On December 12, 1991, Disney selected only one California project to go forward with, Disneyland Resort, which was to include the WestCOT Center, hotels, a shopping mall and a lake. The New York Times, December 13, 1991. Page D1. Port Disney was abandoned in March 1992, and Disney canceled its leases on the Queen Mary and Spruce Goose attractions picked up from the Wrather Corporation.The New York Times, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1992.htm March 7, 1992]. Page 49. [[Mickey's Toontown]], a new themed land at Disneyland, opened on January 24, 1993.Walt Disney - Hollywood's Dark Prince, by Marc Eliot, 1993. Page 279. Disney canceled its plans for WestCOT in mid-1995 due to financial issues at [[Disneyland Paris]] and the park's projected high cost. That park was then replaced by plans for the [[Disney California Adventure|California Adventure]] park, hotels and a retail district.{{cite news|last1=Marr|first1=Merissa|title=Disney's $1 Billion Adventure|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119257768823361264|accessdate=November 16, 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=October 17, 2007|page=B1}} At Walt Disney World, Mickey's Birthdayland closed on April 22, 1991, then reopened on May 26 as Mickey's Starland.Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1996.324, 329, 333 In order to expand Disney World on wetland, on April 23, 1993, the company agreed to form a {{convert|8500|acre|adj=on}} wilderness preserve in Florida.Disney Magazine, Summer 2001. Page 39. The Disney Inn hotel was leased starting February 1, 1994, by the US Army, then purchased on January 12, 1996, and later renamed Shades of Green.130 [[Planet Hollywood]] opened a location in Pleasure Island on December 17, 1994.''The Disney Magazine'', Fall 1995, Volume 30, Number 4. Page 43. The third water park at Walt Disney World, [[Disney's Blizzard Beach]], opened on April 1, 1995.Birnbaum's Walt Disney World 1997, by Hearst Business Publishing, 1996. Page 192. The Magic Kingdom's Tomorrowland was completely refurbished and reopened in June, 1995.Building a Dream - The Art of Disney Architecture, by Beth Dunlop, 1996. Page 192. Taking up a corner of the Magic Kingdom parking lot, the [[Walt Disney World Speedway]] opened on November 28, 1995.[https://d23.com/a-to-z/walt-disney-world-speedway/ Walt Disney World Speedway]. Disney A to Z - The Updated Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1998. Page 597. In 1996, the [[Disney Institute]] opened on February 9,Birnbaum's Walt Disney World 1997, by Hearst Business Publishing, 1996. Page 181. and [[Disney's BoardWalk Resort|Disney's BoardWalk]] opened on July 1.[https://d23.com/a-to-z/boardwalk/ Boardwalk]. Page 62. (1996). Disney A to Z - The Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith. The first of the [[World of Disney]] stores opened in the Disney Village Marketplace on October 3.Smith, Dave. [https://d23.com/a-to-z/world-of-disney/ World of Disney]. Page 62. (1999). Disney A to Z - The Updated Official Encyclopedia. The Downtown Disney district opened in November 1997, combining Disney Village Marketplace and Pleasure Island.Disney Magazine, Spring 1998. Page 31. A fourth theme park, [[Disney's Animal Kingdom]], opened at Disney World the week of April 20, 1998.{{cite news|last1=Lancaster|first1=Cory|title=Animal Kingdom Throws Star-studded Bash|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1998-04-20/news/9804190408_1_walt-disney-animal-kingdom-disney-theme|accessdate=November 12, 2015|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=April 20, 1998}} The first [[Disney Vacation Club|Disney Vacation Club Resorts]], Vacation Club Resort, opened on October 1, 1991, and was renamed Disney's Old Key West Resort in January 1996. These vacation club hotels were operated by Disney Vacation Developments, Inc. as vacation [[timeshares]].The Disney Magazine, Spring 1996, Volume 31, Number 2. Page 18. *Disney A to Z - The Updated Official Encyclopedia, by Dave Smith, 1998. Page 584. The first off-resort vacation club hotel was Vacation Club Resort, which opened on October 1, 1995, in [[Vero Beach, Florida]].[https://d23.com/a-to-z/vacation-club-resort-vero-beach-florida/ "Vacation Club Resort, Vero Beach, Florida"]. Page 584. ''Disney A to Z - The Updated Official Encyclopedia'', by Dave Smith, 1998. Via [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1994jul.htm Chronology of Walt Disney Company (End of 1994)]. In 1993, Premier Cruises discontinued its partnership with Disney for one with [[Warner Bros.]] After failing to reach agreements with [[Carnival Cruise Line|Carnival]] or [[Royal Caribbean International|Royal Caribbean]], Disney announced in 1994 the formation of its own cruise line. The [[Disney Cruise Line]] launched with the Disney Magic ship in 1998 along with its exclusive resort island port of Castaway Cay. Disney reportedly had plans to build a park named [[Disney's America]]. The park was to have been located in [[Haymarket, Virginia]]; {{convert|2300|acre}} of property were purchased from Exxon in 1993.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1993.htm Work in Progress], by Michael Eisner, 1998. Page 321. The history-themed park was announced on November 11, 1993. The plans for the {{convert|3000|acre}} called for a {{convert|150|acre|adj=on}} amusement park, a campground, a golf course, {{convert|2|e6sqft|m2}} of office/commercial space, and 2500 homes.The New York Times, [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1993jul.htm November 12, 1993]. Page A14. With projections indicating that the park would operate at a loss and with opposition in the press, Disney canceled the project on September 15, 1994.''Disney War'', by James Stewart, 2005. Page 190. [[Walt Disney Imagineering]] created [[Disney Fair]], a U.S. traveling attraction, which premiered in September 1996. The fair was poorly attended and was pulled after a few stops. Disney Entertainment Projects (Asia Pacific) Inc., a new Disney Asian Pacific subsidiary, selected a renamed fair called DisneyFest as its first project, taking it to Singapore to open there on October 30, 1997.{{cite news|last1=Matzer|first1=Marla|title=It Didn't Play in Puyallup, so Disney Tries Singapore|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/aug/28/business/fi-26586|accessdate=September 23, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=August 28, 1997}} In November 1995, Disney announced the building of [[Tokyo DisneySea]], to be owned by Oriental along with Tokyo Disneyland. Oriental and Disney signed the DisneySea licensing agreement in November 1997; the theme park was scheduled to open in 2001 at a cost of $2.6 billion.{{cite news|title=Disney, Partner to Build New Tokyo Theme Park|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/nov/27/business/fi-58134|accessdate=August 20, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=Associated Press|date=November 27, 1997}} In December 1998, Walt Disney Attractions added [[Euro Disney S.C.A.|Disneyland Paris]], Disney Regional Entertainment and [[Walt Disney Imagineering]] to its portfolio, which already held Disney World, Disney Cruise Line, Disneyland, and Tokyo Disneyland. Chairman Dick Nunis retired at the same time.{{cite news|last1=Lancaster|first1=Cory|title=Disney's Nunis To Retire|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1998-12-12/business/9812111396_1_walt-disney-disney-world-disney-imagineering|accessdate=August 20, 2015|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=December 12, 1998}} On October 31, 1999, Walt Disney Attractions, Inc. was merged into Walt Disney Attractions, LLC.{{cite web|title=Merger Sheet|url=http://search.sunbiz.org/Inquiry/CorporationSearch/ConvertTiffToPDF?storagePath=COR\1999\1105\00031850.TIF&documentNumber=P25577|website=SunBiz.org|publisher=State of Florida|accessdate=November 17, 2015|format=tif|date=October 28, 1999}} On June 19, 1998, Disney Regional Entertainment opened its first DisneyQuest, a location-based entertainment venue, at Downtown Disney West Side in Walt Disney World.{{cite news|last1=Pecho|first1=Bruce|title=Virtual Reality Rules At Disney's Newest Theme Park|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-05-31/travel/9805310289_1_virtual-jungle-cruise-disneyquest-virtual-reality|accessdate=April 18, 2016|work=Chicago Tribune|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=May 31, 1998}} The first DisneyQuest outside of a resort was opened in Chicago on June 16, 1999, with plans for more locations worldwide.{{cite news|last1=Bigness|first1=Jon|title=Disney's Daring Concept|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-06-16/business/9906160311_1_virtual-jungle-cruise-disney-regional-entertainment-disney-theme-park-experience |accessdate=April 18, 2016 |work=Chicago Tribune|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=June 16, 1999}} In 1999, plans were announced for a new resort in [[Hong Kong]], Hong Kong Disneyland, as a joint venture, Hong Kong International Theme Parks Ltd., between the Hong Kong Government and Disney Resorts.{{cite news|last1=Chung|first1=Yulanda|title=Making A Magic Kingdom|url=http://www.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/magazine/99/1112/cover1.html|accessdate=April 18, 2016|work=Asiaweek|issue=Volume 25, Number 45.|publisher=CNN|date=November 12, 1999}} The ''[[Disney Wonder]]'' cruise ship began operation on August 15.{{cite news|last1=Nefer|first1=Barb|title=Disney Cruise Line History|url=http://traveltips.usatoday.com/disney-cruise-line-history-20748.html|accessdate=April 18, 2016|work=USA Today|agency=Demand Media}} Disney World's [[Discovery Island (Bay Lake)|Discovery Island]] was closed on April 8, 1999.{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Jim|title=Will pirates soon be returning to Treasure ... er ... Discovery Island?|url=http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2008/06/06/will-pirates-soon-be-returning-to-treasure-er-discovery-island.aspx|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=Jim Hill Media|date=June 5, 2008}} ===Walt Disney Parks and Resorts=== Walt Disney Attractions, LLC changed its name to Walt Disney Parks and Resorts, LLC on April 14, 2000, then to Disney Destinations, LLC on April 25, 2006.{{cite web|title=Events: Name History|url=http://search.sunbiz.org/Inquiry/CorporationSearch/NameHistory?aggregateId=flal-l99000007022-1294f8b4-a7e2-4162-b4d2-08fe03fbfb5c&entityId=L99000007022&CurrentPage=0&SearchTerm=Walt%20Disney%20Parks%20and%20Resorts%20Worldwide&InquiryType=EntityName&inquiryDirectionType=CurrentList&SearchNameOrder=WALTDISNEYATTRACTIONS%20L990000070220&ListNameOrder=WALTDIESINGASSOCIATES%20K475700 |website=SunBiz.org|publisher=State of Florida|accessdate=November 17, 2015}} [[Tokyo DisneySea]] at [[Tokyo Disney Resort]] opened on September 4, 2001.{{cite news|title=Disney's New Tokyo Sea-Themed Park Opens|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/sep/05/business/fi-42280|accessdate=August 20, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=|date=September 5, 2001|first=Richard|last=Verrier}} The Walt Disney Company in selling its Japanese and US chains decided to keep the [[Disney Store]]s in Europe, along with the store in Manhattan, which was converted into a [[World of Disney]] store run by Walt Disney Parks and Resorts in 2004.{{cite news|last1=McGeehan|first1=Patrick|title=For Disney, the Magic on Fifth Avenue Ends|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/23/for-disney-the-magic-on-fifth-avenue-ends/comment-page-1/?_r=0|accessdate=November 12, 2015|work=New York Times|date=September 23, 2009}} [[Downtown Disney (Disneyland Resort)|Downtown Disney]] opened at the [[Disneyland Resort]] on January 12, 2001, between Disneyland and the future California Adventure. Pages 23,28. [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2001.htm Disney Magazine]. Fall 2000. Accessed on April 18, 2016. *Page 16. Disney Magazine, Winter 2000-2001. [[Disney California Adventure|Disney California Adventure Park]] opened at the [[Disneyland Resort]] on February 8, 2001, with three major areas: Paradise Pier, Hollywood Pictures Backlot, and the Golden State. In California Adventure on October 6, 2002, A Bug's Land area opened.http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2002.htm Disney Magazine, Spring 2003, Volume 8, Number 2. Page 29. Parks and Resorts chairman Jay Rasulo announced at Disney's D23 Expo in Anaheim, California on September 12, 2009, that Walt Disney World's Fantasyland would be overhauled and increased in size by 2013.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2009.htm Orlando Attractions], Winter 2010. Page 33. Accessed on April 18, 2016. A $1 billion expansion/renovation of [[Disney California Adventure|Disney California Adventure Park]] was announced in 2007 to be completed by 2012.{{cite news|last1=MacDonald|first1=Brady|title=Disney California Adventure: How we got here and what's next |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jun/18/news/la-trb-disney-california-adventure-retrospective-06201217 |accessdate=April 19, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 18, 2012}} [[Disney's River Country|River Country]] water park closed on September 1, 2001.Disney Twenty-three, Fall 2011, Volume 3, Issue 3.Orlando Attractions, October 2008, Volume 1, Number 6. Disney-MGM Studios is renamed [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] in January 2008.{{cite news|last1=Mervine|first1=Bob|title=Disney-MGM Studios to be renamed|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/stories/2007/08/06/daily34.html|accessdate=April 19, 2016|work=Orlando Business Journal|publisher=American City Business Journals|date=August 9, 2007}} [[Pleasure Island (Walt Disney World Resort)|Pleasure Island]]'s core remaining six nightclubs were closed down in late 2008 to change the area to match the family friendly make-up of the other two sections of [[Disney Springs|Downtown Disney]] at Disney World.{{cite news|last1=Powers|first1=Scott|title=The party's over at Pleasure Island: Disney to shut down 6 nightclubs|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-06-28/news/disney28_1_pleasure-island-downtown-disney-downtown-orlando|accessdate=April 19, 2016|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=June 28, 2008}} [[Walt Disney Studios Park]] opened March 16, 2002, as the second theme park at the renamed [[Disneyland Paris|Disneyland Resort Paris]]. The first park was renamed [[Disneyland Park (Paris)|Disneyland Park]] (DLP.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2002.htm Disney Magazine]. Winter 2001-2002. Page 22. *Disney Magazine, Spring 2002. Page 28. *Disney Magazine, Winter 2002, Volume 8, Number 1. Page 54. *Stewart, James (2005). ''Disney War''. Page 387. *Jody Revenson (editor), 2006. Disney Insider Yearbook 2005 Year in Review. Page 81. Accessed on April 19, 2016. DLP Paris opened in August 2000 [[Toy Story Land|Toy Story Playland]] with three attractions.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2009.htm Orlando Attractions], Fall 2010, Volume 3, Number 4. Page 22. Accessed on April 19, 2016. Construction on [[Hong Kong Disneyland]] began on January 12, 2003,Jody Revenson (editor), 2006. ''[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2003.htm Disney Insider Yearbook 2005 Year in Review]''. Page 69. Accessed on April 19, 2016. then opened September 12, 2005.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2005.htm Disney Magazine], Summer 2005, Volume 10, Number 3. Page 33. Accessed on April 19, 2016. *Jody Revenson (editor), 2006. Disney Insider Yearbook 2005 Year in Review]''. Page 5. Groundbreaking occurred at Hong Kong Disneyland in December 2009 for a three land expansion: [[Mystic Point]], [[Grizzly Gulch]], and [[Toy Story Land]].[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2009.htm Orlando Attractions]. Spring 2010, Volume 3, Number 2. Page 61. Accessed on April 19, 2016. In June 2005, Disney Magic made the first cruise outside of the Caribbean, by moving its port for the summer to Los Angeles with a Mexican Riviera schedule. Disney Cruise Line ordered a new 2 ships class from [[Meyer Werft]] shipyard in Germany by February 22, 2007.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2007.htm Oars & Ears]. December 2006, Volume 7, Number 9. Page 7. Accessed on April 19, 2016. The Magic in May 2007 transferred its home port to Barcelona, Spain, for the lines' first summer Mediterranean itinerary then returned to its permanent port in September. The Chicago DisneyQuest location was closed in September 2001.{{cite news|last1=Elder|first1=Robert K.|title=What went wrong at DisneyQuest? |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-07-16/features/0107160127_1_disneyquest-family-entertainment-entertainment-companies |accessdate=April 18, 2016 |work=Chicago Tribune |publisher=Tribune Publishing |date=July 16, 2001}} Disney Parks started the [[Adventures by Disney]] tour vacation business in 2005.{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Terry |title=Adventures by Disney: Long weekends, Disney-style |url= http://experience.usatoday.com/weekend/story/my-weekend-experience/2015/02/24/adventures-by-disney-weekend-trips/23950735/ |accessdate=April 19, 2016|work=USA Today |date=February 24, 2015 }} Disney entered a float, "The Most Magical Celebration on Earth", into the 2006 Pasadena [[Rose Parade|Tournament of Roses parade]].Jody Revenson (editor), 2006. [http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2006.htm Disney Insider Yearbook 2005 Year in Review]''. Page 5. Accessed on April 19, 2016. In October 2007, Disney announced plans to build a resort at Ko Olina Resort & Marina in [[Kapolei, Hawaii]], featuring both a hotel and Disney Vacation Club timeshare units. The 800-unit property, named [[Aulani]], opened in 2011 and joined the other resorts not associated with a theme park, such as [[Disney's Hilton Head Island Resort]] in South Carolina.{{cite news | title=Aloha, Disney | url=http://starbulletin.com/2007/10/04/news/story01.html | work=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] | first=Allison | last=Schaefers | date=October 4, 2007 | accessdate=October 6, 2007}} With the Walt Disney World Millennium Celebration starting on October 1, 2000, sanctioned Disney Pin Trading was started. *(December 2008). ''[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn1999jul.htm Orlando Attractions]''. Volume 2, Number 1. Page 32. Accessed on April 18, 2016. *(September 23, 1999). ''Eyes & Ears''. Volume 29, Number 38. Page 5. Accessed on April 18, 2016. In 2001, the Themed Entertainment Association gave Disney Parks and Resorts the Thea Award for Breakthrough Innovation for the park's FastPass system.Strodder, Chris. (2008). ''[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2001.htm The Disneyland Encyclopedia]''. Page 166. Accessed on April 19, 2016. ===Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Worldwide=== Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Worldwide, Inc. was incorporated on September 29, 2008, buy out and took over the parks and resorts business segment. Disney Parks and Resorts reorganized in early 2009 which included layoffs in all units due to recession-induced falling attendance. 600 U.S. managers in January were buyout packages. Worldwide Operations was formed under President Al Weiss in 2009. Worldwide Operations would take over various back office functions previously performed by both Disney World and Disneyland including training, procurement, menu planning and merchandise development. While its Walt Disney Imagineering subsidiary combined its three development units.{{cite news |last1=Chmielewski |first1=Dawn C. |title=Disney combines theme park functions in prelude to job cuts |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2009/feb/19/business/fi-disney19 |accessdate=September 22, 2015 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=February 19, 2009}} In November 2009, Disney received approval from the Chinese government to build a [[Shanghai Disneyland|Disneyland resort]] in [[Shanghai]]'s [[Pudong]] district.{{cite web|title=Shanghai Disneyland Project Gets Approval|url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsworld.php?id=452465|accessdate=June 21, 2012}} The resort opened on June 16, 2016.{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Thomas|title=Opening Date Set for Shanghai Disney Resort, Disney’s Newest World-Class Destination|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2016/01/opening-date-set-for-shanghai-disney-resort-disneys-newest-world-classdestination/|publisher=DisneyParks Blog|accessdate=January 14, 2016|date=January 12, 2016}} California Adventure completed its overhaul in 2012 adding two new lands: [[Cars Land]] and [[Buena Vista Street]]. The overhaul also included a re-themed of several attractions plus a pair of classic dark rides. In 2017, it was announced that [[Paradise Pier]] land would be replaced by Pixar Pier, with four neighborhoods, and the remainder not in Pixar Pier would be replaced by Paradise Park. Pixar Pier opened on June 23, 2018.{{cite web | last=Ramirez | first=Michael | title=Pixar Pier Now Open to Guests at Disney California Adventure Park | website=Disney Parks Blog | date=June 23, 2018 | url=https://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2018/06/pixar-pier-now-open-to-guests-at-disney-california-adventure-park/ | access-date=September 23, 2018}} [[Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge|''Star Wars'': Galaxy's Edge]], a {{convert|14|acre|ha|adj=on}} themed land for both [[Disneyland]] and [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] announced at the [[D23 (Disney)|D23 Expo]] on August 15, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Pedicini|first1=Sandra |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/travel/attractions/the-daily-disney/os-star-wars-disney-hollywood-studios-20150815-story.html|title=Star Wars land coming to Disney's Hollywood Studios|date=August 15, 2015|work=Orlando Sentinel}} Construction began at both locations on April 14, 2016.{{cite news|last1=Parker|first1=Ryan|title=Disney Breaks Ground on 'Star Wars' Land in California and Florida|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disneys-star-wars-land-photos-883997|accessdate=April 14, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 14, 2016}} The lands at both parks are scheduled to open in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2018/05/opening-season-just-announced-for-star-wars-galaxys-edge/|title=Opening Season Just Announced for Star Wars: Galaxy’s Edge|work=Disney Parks Blog|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|accessdate=June 15, 2018|date=May 22, 2018|first=Scott|last=Trowbridge|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}} The New Fantasyland at Magic Kingdom opened on December 6, 2012. It is the biggest upgrade to the theme park since its opening in 1971.{{cite news|last1=Sekula|first1=Sarah|title=Disney brings more oomph with New Fantasyland|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/05/travel/disney-new-fantasyland/|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=CNN.com|publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc.|date=December 10, 2012}} Announced along with its new Star Wars Land expansion at the D23 Expo on August 15, 2015, Hollywood Studios was slated to have a version of [[Toy Story Land]].{{cite news| last1=Kubersky|first1=Seth|title=Updated Toy Story Land concept art unveiled at Disney’s Hollywood Studios|url=http://attractionsmagazine.com/updated-toy-story-land-concept-art-unveiled-disneys-hollywood-studios/ | accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=Attractions Magazine|publisher=Dream Together Media, LLC|date=April 4, 2016}} Holz became president of New Vacation Operations of Parks & Resorts{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2009-02-14/news/dizcruise14_1_disney-cruise-line-disney-declined-mcalpin|title=Familiar face takes Disney Cruise Line helm: Karl Holz|last1=Garcia|first1=Jason|date=February 14, 2009|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=April 9, 2017}} reporting to [[Al Weiss]], president of worldwide operations for Walt Disney Parks and Resorts.{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Jason|title=Disney executive changes: Head of Disney's theme parks makes executive changes|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-07-05/the-daily-disney/os-disney-executive-changes-20110705_1_al-weiss-crofton-resorts-chairman-tom-staggs|accessdate=April 13, 2017|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=July 5, 2011|language=en}} by April 2008.{{cite press release | author = | title = Philippe Gas to Assume Top Duties at Euro Disney | url = http://corporate.disneylandparis.com/CORP/EN/Neutral/Images/uk-2008-04-10-nomination-philippe-gas.pdf | format = PDF | location =Marne-la-Vallée | publisher =Euro Disney S.C.A. | date = April 11, 2008 | access-date = April 14, 2016}} In February 2009, Holz returned to the presidency of Disney Cruise Line in addition to his continuing as head of New Vacation Operations, which was primarily [[Adventures by Disney]]. As an extension of the "One Disney" initiative and the resignation of Weiss, Disney Vacation Club was added to New Vacation Operations. While Holz and Meg Crofton joined Disney Parks and Resorts executive committee in July 2011. At that time, Crofton was transferred from Disney World president to president of operations in the U.S. and France, a new positions. The ''Disney Dream'' began service in January 2011 and [[Disney Cruise Line]] (DCL) announced the maiden voyage of the ''[[Disney Fantasy]]'' to be March 31, 2012. The Dream deployment allowed Disney Wonder to be permanently stationed at Port of Los Angeles for Mexican Riviera cruises,{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Jason|title=Disney sets maiden voyage for new cruise ship|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2010-10-18/the-daily-disney/os-new-disney-cruise-ship-20101018_1_disney-magic-disney-cruise-line-disney-dream|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=October 18, 2010}} but initial served in the short Alaska cruise season. Magic moved to New York for Canadian or Bahama cruises starting May 25, 2012.[http://kpolsson.com/disnehis/disn2009.htm Cruise Travel]. July 2011, Volume 33, Number 1. Page 36. DCL's Magic was refitted in late 2013.{{cite news|title=Major Refit Planned for Disney Magic|url=https://www.cruiseindustrynews.com/cruise-news/9130-major-refit-planned-for-disney-magic.html|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=Cruise Industry News|date=April 26, 2013}} The first of three expansion theme lands at Hong Kong Disneyland, [[Toy Story Land]], opened on November 18, 2011.{{cite news|last1=Li|first1=Zoe|title=Toy Story Land hopes to save Hong Kong Disney|url=http://travel.cnn.com/hong-kong/visit/how-toy-story-land-hopes-save-hong-kong-disney-081206/|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=CNN.com|publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc.|date=November 21, 2011}} [[Grizzly Gulch]] opened at Hong Kong Disneyland on July 13, 2012.{{cite news|last1=Guinigundo|first1=Andy|title=Out of the Loop: Hong Kong Disneyland debuts Grizzly Gulchf|url=http://attractionsmagazine.com/out-of-the-loop-hong-kong-disneyland-debuts-grizzly-gulch/|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=Attractions Magazine|publisher=Dream Together Media, LLC.|date=July 31, 2012}} The final land of this expansion, [[Mystic Point]], opened at Hong Kong Disneyland on May 17, 2013.{{cite news|title=Hong Kong Disneyland's Mystic Point opens May 17|url=http://www.ttgasia.com/article.php?article_id=20853|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=TTG Asia|date=April 19, 2013}} On February 5, 2015, it was announced that [[Thomas O. Staggs|Tom Staggs]] had been promoted to Disney Company [[Chief operating officer]] but would continue as chairman of Parks and Resorts until his successor was named.{{cite web| last1=Littleton |first1=Cynthia |title=Disney Promotes Tom Staggs to No. 2 Post, Positioning Him as Iger’s Successor |url=https://variety.com/2015/biz/news/disney-promotes-tom-staggs-to-no-2-post-positioning-him-as-igers-successor-1201423601/|website=Variety.com|publisher=Variety Magazine|accessdate=February 5, 2015}} On February 23, 2015, Robert Chapek was named chairman of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts effective that day.{{cite news|last1=Barnes|first1=Brooks|title=Disney Names Robert Chapek Chairman for Theme Parks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/24/business/media/disney-names-robert-chapek-chairman-for-theme-parks.html?_r=0|accessdate=February 26, 2015|work=New York Times|date=February 23, 2015}} On April 29, 2015, The Walt Disney Company, through the subsidiary, Carousel Holdings Eat LLC, has purchased Carousel Inn & Suites hotel in Anaheim, from Good Hope International for $32 million. The purchase was considered a strategic purchase; the hotel would not be considered a part of the Disneyland hotel portfolio and would operate independently.{{cite web|last1=Pimentel|first1=Joseph|title=Disney purchases Carousel Inn for $32 million |url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/disney-659941-hotel-inn.html|website=OCRegister.com|publisher=The Orange County Register|date=April 29, 2015}} Disney indicted in August 2016, that the company would be closing the Carousel Inn in October 2016 in preparation for razing it as part of plans to construct a new parking structure, transit plaza, and pedestrian bridge over Harbor Boulevard.{{cite web|last1=Pimentel|first1=Joseph|title=Q&A Disneyland's massive parking project|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/disney-725945-harbor-bridge.html|website=OCRegister.com|publisher=The Orange County Register|date=August 16, 2016}} On February 10, 2017, Disney revealed a deal to purchase [[Kingdom Holding]] Co.'s shares of [[Euro Disney S.C.A.]] as first step in purchasing the remaining shares held by others. Disney has offered about $2.12 a share, a 67% premium over the Euronext Paris Stock Exchange value as of February 9. The company expects the buyout and delisting to be finished by June. Plans are for the company to invest another $1.4 billion into Disneyland Paris after the buyout to counteract the recent [[November 2015 Paris attacks|Paris terrorist attack]], which hurt a previous 2014 park hotel investment. If this buyout is successful, it would make the resort the only resort 100% owned and operated by Disney outside of the United States of America.{{cite news|last1=Littleton|first1=Cynthia|title=Disney Seeks Full Ownership of Disneyland Paris|url=https://variety.com/2017/biz/news/disneyland-paris-disney-buyout-terrorist-attack-1201984089/|accessdate=February 16, 2017|work=Variety|date=February 10, 2017}} On June 13, 2017, The Walt Disney Company reached the 95% threshold required for a mandatory takeover according to French law, owning 97.08% of Euro Disney S.C.A., paving the way for The Walt Disney Company to become the sole owner and operator of Disneyland Paris.{{Cite news|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/final-results-of-the-simplified-public-tender-offer-on-euro-disney-sca-the-walt-disney-company-to-implement-a-mandatory-buy-out-and-delisting-2017-06-13-102035936|title=Final results of the simplified public tender offer on Euro Disney S.C.A. The Walt Disney Company to implement a mandatory buy-out and delisting|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2017-06-13|language=en-US}} As part of [[The Walt Disney Company]]’s March 2018 strategic reorganization, Walt Disney Parks and Resorts merged with Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media segments into [[Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products]]. Parks and Resorts chairman Bob Chapek was named chairman of this new segment, who also previously served as head of Disney Consumer Products.{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Christine|title=Disney announces strategic reorganization, effective immediately|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/14/disney-announces-strategic-reorganization-effective-immediately.html|accessdate=March 14, 2018|work=CNBC|date=March 14, 2018}} ==Disney resorts== {{location map+|Earth |float=center |width=750 |caption=Locations of Disney resorts |places= {{Location map~|Earth|position=top|lat=31.144|long=121.657|label='''[[Shanghai Disney Resort]]''' }} {{Location map~|Earth|position=bottom|lat=22.313333|long=114.043333|label='''[[Hong Kong Disneyland Resort]]''' }} {{Location map~|Earth|position=right|lat=48.868719|long=2.7818|label='''[[Disneyland Paris]]''' }} {{Location map~|Earth|position=right|lat=35.629722|long=139.882778|label='''[[Tokyo Disney Resort]]''' }} {{Location map~|Earth|position=right|lat=28.418611|long=-81.581111|label='''[[Walt Disney World]]''' }} {{Location map~|Earth|position=left|lat=33.8091|long=-117.919|label='''[[Disneyland Resort]]''' }} }} ===Disneyland Resort=== {{Main|Disneyland Resort}} [[Disneyland]] was founded as a single park by [[Walt Disney]] and opened on July 17, 1955, in [[Anaheim, California]]. [[Disneyland Hotel (California)|Disneyland Hotel]] opened to the public on October 5, 1955. In 2001, the site expanded significantly and was renamed the Disneyland Resort with the opening of [[Disney California Adventure|Disney California Adventure Park]] on February 8, 2001, [[Disney's Grand Californian Hotel & Spa]] on January 2, 2001, [[Disney's Paradise Pier Hotel]] on December 15, 2000, and [[Downtown Disney (Disneyland Resort)|Downtown Disney]] on January 12, 2001. Disneyland was rebranded Disneyland Park to distinguish it from the larger resort complex. The resort focuses on [[Mickey Mouse]] and other Disney characters and occupies {{convert|500|acre|km2}}. ===Walt Disney World=== {{Main|Walt Disney World}} The Walt Disney World Resort opened October 1, 1971, in [[Lake Buena Vista, Florida]], with the [[Magic Kingdom]] theme park and three resort hotels. It expanded with the opening of [[Epcot]] in 1982, Disney-MGM Studios (now [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]]) and [[Disney's Typhoon Lagoon]] in 1989, [[Disney's Blizzard Beach]] in 1995, [[Disney's Animal Kingdom]] in 1998, [[Disney Springs]] retail, dining, and entertainment complex, eight golf courses, and 18 new resort hotels. The resort is the largest (by area) and most-visited vacation resort in the world, with four theme parks, two water parks, a shopping, dining, and entertainment complex, 21 resort hotels, eight golf courses, and several additional recreational activities, and covers 27,258 acres of land. Other venues: * [[ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex]] ===Tokyo Disney Resort=== {{Main|Tokyo Disney Resort}} '''Tokyo Disney Resort''', located in [[Urayasu, Chiba]], Japan, opened April 15, 1983, with [[Tokyo Disneyland]]. On September 4, 2001, the resort expanded with [[Tokyo DisneySea]]. There are several resort hotels on site, but only three are actually owned by the resort, which boasts the largest parking structure in the world. Tokyo Disney Resort is fully owned and operated by [[The Oriental Land Company]] and is licensed by The Walt Disney Company. The resort was built by [[Walt Disney Imagineering]], and Disney maintains a degree of control; Nick Franklin leads the Walt Disney Attractions Japan team at The Walt Disney Company, which communicates with the Oriental Land Company over all aspects of the Resort, and assigns Imagineers to the Resort. Its properties, listed below, are divided into parks, shopping centers, and lodging. *Shopping, dining, and entertainment complex: [[Ikspiari]] ===Disneyland Paris=== {{Main|Disneyland Paris}} '''Disneyland Paris''', Disney's second resort complex outside the United States, opened on April 12, 1992, as the '''Euro Disney Resort'''. Located in [[Marne-la-Vallée]] in the suburbs of Paris, France, it features two theme parks, a golf course, an entertainment complex, and seven Disney resort hotels. It is the only resort out of the United States fully owned and operated by [[The Walt Disney Company]]. Its properties sit on {{convert|4940|acre|km2}}, listed below, and are divided into parks and shopping centers. ===Hong Kong Disneyland Resort=== {{Main|Hong Kong Disneyland Resort}} '''Hong Kong Disneyland Resort''', Disney's fifth resort and its second in Asia, opened September 12, 2005. The resort is located in [[Penny's Bay]], [[Lantau Island]], Hong Kong. The resort consists of [[Hong Kong Disneyland]] theme park, [[Inspiration Lake Recreation Centre]], and three hotels, with land reserved for future expansion. It is owned and operated by [[Hong Kong International Theme Parks]], an incorporated company jointly owned by [[The Walt Disney Company]] and the [[Government of Hong Kong]]. The first phase of Hong Kong Disneyland Resort occupies {{convert|320|acre|km2}}. ===Shanghai Disney Resort=== {{Main|Shanghai Disney Resort}} In November 2009, Disney received approval from the central government of China to build a Disney theme park, [[Shanghai Disneyland Park]], in [[Shanghai]]'s [[Pudong]] district. "China is one of the most dynamic, exciting and important countries in the world and this approval marks a very significant milestone for Walt Disney Co in mainland China," said Robert Iger, president and CEO of Disney.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssTechMediaTelecomNews/idUSN0352328120091104 | work=Reuters | title=UPDATE 4-Disney takes China stride as Shanghai park gets nod | date=November 4, 2009}} The resort opened on June 16, 2016. A groundbreaking ceremony took place on April 7, 2011.{{cite news| url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Business/Disneyland-China-Disney-Agrees-A-Deal-To-Open-Amusement-Park-In-Shanghai/Article/201011115795782?f=rss | work=Sky News | title=Disney To Bring Magic Kingdom To Shanghai | date=November 5, 2010 | accessdate=November 5, 2010}} ==Training== Founded by Walt Disney in 1955, each new employee at a Disney theme park is trained at a Disney University. Before classes and on-the-job training specific to the job they will be performing in the park, each employee attends the "Disney Traditions" course where they learn of the philosophies and history of Disney's guest services.{{cite book|last1=Yearout|first1=Steve|last2=Weil|first2=Gerry Miles, with Richard Koonce ; foreword by Audrey|title=Growing leaders : a leader-builder handbook for HRD and training professionals, business executives and managers, executive coaches|date=2001|publisher=ASTD|location=Alexandria, VA|isbn=1562862898|page=193}}{{cite book|last1=Lipp|first1=Doug|title=Disney U : how Disney University develops the world's most engaged, loyal, and customer-centric employees|date=2013|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=New York|isbn=0071808078}} ==Abandoned and misreported concepts== Disney had plans to build [[Walt Disney's Riverfront Square]] in [[St. Louis]]. In July 1965, Disney canceled the project. In the 1960s, Disney initiated a plan for a ski resort at [[Mineral King]] in California. Opposition from environmental groups led by the [[Sierra Club]] led to a temporary court injunction in 1969 and legal battles through the 1970s. The project's planning and scale changed multiple times, and in 1978, Mineral King was annexed into [[Sequoia National Park]], ending any possibility of developing a ski resort.{{cite book|title=Challenge of the Big Trees|last=Dilsaver|first=L.M.|author2=Tweed, W.C. |chapter=New Directions and a Second Century (1972–1990)|year=1990|publisher=Sequoia Natural History Association |chapterurl= http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/dilsaver-tweed/chap9c.htm}} Disney reportedly had plans to build a park named [[Disney's America]]. The park was to have been located in [[Haymarket, Virginia]], but local opposition to the idea persuaded Disney to abandon the idea in 1994. On September 28, 1994, [[Michael Eisner]] announced that Disney was canceling its plans to build Disney's America after a bruising national media fight with Protect Historic America and aggressive local opposition in Virginia from Protect Prince William and other citizen groups. Disney had plans to build a Disneyland in Sydney, Australia, between 2007 and 2008 with the proposed name "Disney Wharf at Sydney Harbour", but the concept was abandoned due to mixed responses in the [[Government of New South Wales|New South Wales Government]].{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/walt-disney-company-proposed-a-disney-resort-in-sydney-20140111-30nfk.html|title=Walt Disney Company proposed a Disney Resort in Sydney|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=October 4, 2014}} In early January 2011, conflicting reports emerged regarding Disney's involvement in a proposed entertainment complex in Haifa, Israel, whose plans include a small (30,000 square meter) amusement park scheduled to open in 2013. The project will be partially funded by [[Shamrock Holdings]], a Disney-affiliated investment firm. In the wake of reports from Israeli business newspaper ''[[Globes]]'' and industry newswire ''Amusement Management'' that Disney itself would be involved in the project's development, a spokesperson for Walt Disney Parks and Resorts clarified to ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' that Disney did not have any plans to involve itself in the building of the park.Ungerleider, Neal. [http://www.fastcompany.com/1714452/disney-to-open-theme-park-in-israel "Disney to Open Theme Park in Israel?"] ''Fast Company''. January 5, 2011. ==Future projects== It was reported in August 2014 that beginning in 2015, Disney planned to expand the presence of ''[[Star Wars]]'' throughout their theme parks (though it was initially unclear which parks) and could also create an entire theme park area dedicated to the film franchise. Disney Chairman and CEO [[Bob Iger]] indicated that plans were to match what [[Universal Orlando Resort|Universal Orlando]] did when they expanded and added a [[Harry Potter]] themed section to two of their theme parks. In 2012, Disney acquired [[Lucasfilm]], which includes the rights to the ''Star Wars'' franchise and ''[[Indiana Jones]]'' franchise (which is also expected to see an increase in presence at the theme parks), and in December 2015, Disney released ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'', the first of a new trilogy of films.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/disney-bring-more-star-wars-attractions-theme-parks-111904441.html|title=Disney to bring more 'Star Wars' attractions to its theme parks|publisher=Yahoo.com|date=August 6, 2015|accessdate=August 6, 2014}}{{Better source|reason=not the original source, AFP Relaxnews, and Yahoo will drop the page at some point|date=October 2015}} [[Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge]] was announced on August 15, 2015 as Star Wars Land, and is currently under construction at the Disneyland Resort in California and Disney's Hollywood Studios in Florida. Both lands are set to open in 2019. At D23 Expo 2017, Disney Parks chairman Bob Chapek revealed Galaxy's Edge as the area's official name, announcing an attraction set inside the hangar bay of a First Order Star Destroyer. The Disneyland version of Galaxy's Edge is currently slated to open first, with the Walt Disney World version following later in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2017/07/star-wars-galaxys-edge-announced-as-name-for-star-wars-lands-at-disney-parks/|title=Star Wars: Galaxy’s Edge Announced as Name for Star Wars Lands at Disney Parks|publisher=disneyparks.disney.go.com|date=July 15, 2017|accessdate=August 26, 2017}} In addition, it was announced that a Star Wars-themed hotel and resort are planned for Walt Disney World; the company aims for guest experiences to be "100% immersive", with Chapek claiming that each guest's stay will "culminate in a unique journey".{{cite news|last1=Bevil|first1=Dewayne|title=Disney's 'Star Wars' hotel would escalate immersion trend, experts say|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/travel/attractions/the-daily-disney/os-bz-disney-star-wars-hotel-immersive-20170725-story.html|accessdate=January 9, 2018|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=July 25, 2017}} In September 2011, Walt Disney Parks and Resorts announced plans to partner with filmmaker [[James Cameron]] and his [[Lightstorm Entertainment]] production company, along with [[20th Century Fox]], to develop theme park attractions based on Cameron's ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' film franchise, with the first installation planned for [[Disney's Animal Kingdom]] at [[Walt Disney World]], in the form of [[Pandora – The World of Avatar|a themed land]]. The expansion, named "Pandora—The World of Avatar", opened on May 27, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/biz/news/disney-pushing-boundaries-with-avatar-land-at-animal-kingdom-theme-park-1201442369/|title=Disney Provides Update of ‘Avatar’ Land at Animal Kingdom - Variety|author=Marc Graser|work=Variety}} Future Avatar-themed lands could be built for the other Disney Resorts, including the locations in Shanghai and Hong Kong. Both Hong Kong Disneyland Resort and Disneyland Paris Resort have room for future expansion.{{cite news | title=Disney in talks to open theme park in Shanghai – report | url=https://www.forbes.com/markets/feeds/afx/2006/02/07/afx2507986.html | work=[[AFX News Limited]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918213515/http://www.forbes.com/markets/feeds/afx/2006/02/07/afx2507986.html|archivedate=September 18, 2008 |date=February 7, 2006 | accessdate=November 15, 2007}} CEO [[Robert Iger]] frequently has cited international expansion as one of the company's three strategic priorities.{{cite web |title=Top Executive Profiles - Robert A. Iger - Portfolio.com |url=http://www.portfolio.com:80/resources/executive-profiles/39787 |website=Portfolio.com |date=December 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212205014/http://www.portfolio.com/resources/executive-profiles/39787 |archivedate=December 12, 2007 |df= }} ==Properties outside Disney parks== Due to its acquisitions of [[Marvel Entertainment]] in 2009 and [[Lucasfilm]] in 2012, some Disney-owned franchises are represented in its competitors' parks. [[Marvel Super Hero Island]], a themed land featuring characters and settings from [[Marvel Comics]], has operated at [[Universal Orlando]] Resort's [[Islands of Adventure]] park since 1999, as well as the Islands of Adventure cloned ride ''[[The Amazing Adventures of Spider-Man]]'' at [[Universal Studios Japan]] since 2004. Under Marvel's 1994 agreement with [[Universal Parks & Resorts]] in regional terms, none of the Marvel characters and other persons related to such characters (e.g., side characters, team members, and the villains associated with the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]], [[Fantastic Four]], [[X-Men]], [[Spider-Man]], etc.) connected with Islands of Adventure and Universal Studios Japan can be used at Walt Disney World and Tokyo Disney Resort.{{cite web|last1=Munarriz|first1=Rick|title=Disney is Taking Too Long to Add Marvel to Disneyland and Disney World|url=http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2015/10/18/disney-is-taking-too-long-to-add-marvel-to-disney.aspx|website=The Motley Fool|accessdate=January 17, 2016}} [[Disneyland Resort]], Walt Disney World, and Tokyo Disney also cannot use the Marvel name as part of an attraction or marketing and the Marvel-themed [[simulator ride]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1262449/000119312510008732/dex1057.htm|title=Marvel Agreement between MCA Inc. and Marvel Entertainment Group|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|website=sec.gov}} This clause has allowed Walt Disney World to have meet and greets with Marvel characters not associated with the ones at Islands of Adventure, such as [[Star-Lord]] and [[Gamora]] from ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)|Guardians of the Galaxy]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethemagic.net/2014/08/guardians-of-the-galaxy-theme-park-characters-appear-for-first-time-as-walt-disney-world-welcomes-marvel/|title=Guardians of the Galaxy theme park characters appear for first time as Walt Disney World welcomes Marvel|work=Inside the Magic}}{{cite web|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2014/07/exclusive-guardians-of-the-galaxy-sneak-peek-debuts-july-4-at-disney-parks/|title=Exclusive ‘Guardians of the Galaxy’ Sneak Peek Debuts July 4 at Disney Parks|work=Disney Parks Blog}} as well as [[Baymax]] and [[Hiro Takachiho|Hiro]] from ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]''.{{cite web|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2014/11/the-stars-of-big-hero-6-are-ready-for-their-disney-parks-debut/|title=The Stars of ‘Big Hero 6′ Are Ready for Their Disney Parks Debut|work=Disney Parks Blog}} Hong Kong Disneyland, Shanghai Disneyland, and Disneyland Paris either have or planned to incorporate meet and greets as well as attractions relating to the Marvel characters, as well as using the Marvel name and the Marvel simulator ride. A ''[[Star Wars]]''-themed section of [[Legoland California]]'s [[Legoland California#Miniland USA|Miniland USA]] opened in 2011, with a similar version opening at [[Legoland Florida]]{{cite web|url=http://florida.legoland.com/map-explore/land-views/miniland/attractions/lego-star-wars/|title=LEGO® STAR WARS™|publisher=}} in November 2012, just weeks after Disney's acquisition of Lucasfilm and the ''Star Wars'' franchise. [[IMG Worlds of Adventure]] in [[Dubai]] has a Marvel-themed section.https://www.imgworlds.com/language/en/# ==Adaptations== While Disney Parks generally adapt movies into rides, some Disney theme park attractions have been adapted into or have served inspiration for films,{{cite news|last1=Verrier|first1=Richard|title=Movies Imitate Disney's Parks|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/may/15/business/fi-disney15|accessdate=April 1, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 15, 2002}} books, comic books, and [[television pilot]]s. Disney entered the television field with a network TV show named after [[Walt Disney anthology television series|Disneyland]] (which was then its only park, and was being built at the time), in order to fund the park. In this series, some episodes featured the park or a park attraction.{{cite book|last1=Griffin|first1=Sean|title=Encyclopedia of Television|publisher=The Museum of Broadcast Communications|url=http://www.museum.tv/eotv/waltdisneyp.htm|accessdate=April 1, 2017|chapter=Walt Disney Programs}} The Walt Disney Company pioneered and is the only film company and theme park company to have converted theme park attractions to film productions. However, lackluster results were achieved for most of these films except for the [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|Pirates Of The Caribbean]] series.{{cite news|last1=Bacle|first1=Ariana |title=Theme park ride-based movies: Will 'Small World' follow the trend?|url=http://ew.com/article/2014/04/23/disney-theme-park-movies-small-world/ |accessdate= March 28, 2017 |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=April 23, 2014}} Disney Pictures made two [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|Pirates Of The Caribbean]] sequels in 2006 and 2011 that made over a billion-dollar at the box office.{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/beauty-and-the-beast-sean-bailey-disney-emma-watson-1202047710/ |title=Sean Bailey On How Disney’s Live-Action Division Found Its ‘Beauty And The Beast’ Mojo |date=March 21, 2017 |work=Deadline |publisher=Penske Business Media, LLC |last1=Jr|first1=Mike Fleming|accessdate=March 23, 2017}} At first, Disney had merely dabbled with this type of film. [[Walt Disney Television#Disney Telefilms|Disney Telefilms]] made the first movie-based-on-ride, [[Tower of Terror (1997 film)|Tower of Terror]], for the [[Walt Disney anthology television series|Wonderful World of Disney]] anthology television series in 1997.{{cite news|title=Disney Sets ABC Pix|url=https://variety.com/1997/scene/vpage/disney-sets-abc-pix-1117342089/|accessdate=December 30, 2015|work=Variety|date=May 1, 1997}} In 2000, [[Touchstone Pictures]] made ''[[Mission to Mars]]'' based on the [[Mission to Mars (attraction)|closed ride of the same name]].{{cite news|last1=Schwarzbaum|first1=Lisa|title=Mission to Mars|url=http://ew.com/article/2000/03/17/mission-mars-4/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=March 17, 2000}} [[Walt Disney Pictures]] took the [[Country Bear Jamboree]] attraction and made it into ''[[The Country Bears]]'' in 2002. In 2003, Walt Disney Pictures issued two ride-based films in ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl]]'' and ''[[The Haunted Mansion (film)|The Haunted Mansion]]''. ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' launched [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|a film series and a franchise]]. After four Pirates sequels, the franchise took in more than $5.4 billion worldwide.{{cite news|last1=McNary |first1=Dave |last2=Graser |first2=Marc |url=https://variety.com/2013/biz/news/end-of-an-era-disney-and-jerry-bruckheimer-part-ways-1200652789/ |title=End of an Era: Disney and Jerry Bruckheimer Part Ways |date=September 19, 2013 |work=Variety |publisher= |accessdate=March 28, 2017}} [[Disney Publishing Worldwide]] started mining Disney Parks with its [[The Kingdom Keepers]] series. The first novel of the series, ''Disney after Dark'', was released in 2005.{{cite web|title=The Kingdom Keepers (review)|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/ridley-pearson/the-kingdom-keepers/|publisher=Kirkus Reviews|date=August 15, 2005|accessdate=April 9, 2014}} A five-book series was laid out by Pearson, but was extended to seven with the first book's success.{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Jim|title=Keeping up with Disney's "Kingdom Keepers" : Ridley Pearson talks about all the research that goes into this popular book series|url=http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2011/04/03/keeping-up-with-disney-s-quot-kingdom-keepers-quot-ridley-pearson-talks-about-all-the-research-he-does-for-this-popular-book-series.aspx|accessdate=May 1, 2017|work=jimhillmedia.com|date=April 3, 2011|language=en}} With the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise as Disney Pictures' top franchise, the company had been looking for additional projects in this category for a decade.{{cite news|last=Breznican|first=Anthony|title=Disney's mysterious '1952' movie has a new name ... 'Tomorrowland' |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/01/28/disneys-1952-is-tomorrowland/|accessdate=January 29, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=January 28, 2013}} Disney Pictures took another push at additional adaptations in the 2010s.
